play.title: The History of Troilus and Creſſida

speech.speaker: The Prologue.
speech.line: In Troy there lyes the Scene: From Iles of Greece
The Princes Orgillous, their high blood chaf’d
Haue to the Port of Athens ſent their ſhippes
Fraught with the ministers and instruments
Of cruell Warre: Sixty and nine that wore
Their Crownets Regall, from th’ Athenian bay
Put forth toward Phrygia, and their vow is made
To ransacke Troy, within whose ſtrong emures
The rauish’d Helen, Menelaus Queene,
With wanton Paris ſleepes, and that’s the Quarrell.
To Tenedos they come,
And the deepe-drawing Barke do there disgorge
Their warlike frautage: now on Dardan Plaines
The fresh and yet vnbruised Greekes do pitch
Their braue Pauillions. Priams ſix-gated City,
Dardan and Timbria, Helias, Chetas, Troien,
And Antenoridus with maſſie Staples
And corresponsiue and fulfilling Bolts
Stirre vp the Sonnes of Troy.
Now Expectation tickling ſkittish ſpirits,
On one and other ſide, Troian and Greeke,
Sets all on hazard. And hither am I come,
A Prologue arm’d, but not in confidence
Of Authors pen, or Actors voyce; but ſuited
In like conditions, as our Argument;
To tell you (faire Beholders) that our Play
Leapes ore the vaunt and firstlings of those broyles,
Beginning in the middle: ſtarting thence away,
To what may be digested in a Play:
Like, or finde fault, do as your pleasures are,
Now good, or bad, ‘tis but the chance of Warre.

speech.speaker: Troylus.
speech.line: Call here my Varlet, Ile vnarme againe.
Why ſhould I warre without the wals of Troy
That finde ſuch cruell battell here within?
Each Troian that is master of his heart,
Let him to field, Troylus alas hath none.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Will this geere nere be mended?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: The Greeks are ſtrong, & ſkilful to their ſtrength,
Fierce to their ſkill, and to their fierceneſſe Valiant:
But I am weaker then a womans teare;
Tamer then ſleepe, fonder then ignorance;
Leſſe valiant then the Virgin in the night,
And ſkilleſſe as vnpractis’d Infancie.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Well, I haue told you enough of this: For my part, Ile not meddle nor make no farther. Hee that will haue a Cake out of the Wheate, must needes tarry the grinding.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Haue I not tarried?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I the grinding; but you must tarry the bolting.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Haue I not tarried?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I the boulting; but you must tarry the leau'ning,

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Still haue I tarried.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I, to the leauening: but heeres yet in the word hereafter, the Kneading, the making of the Cake, the heating of the Ouen, and the Baking; nay, you must ſtay the cooling too, or you may chance to burne your lips.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Patience her ſelfe, what Goddeſſe ere ſhe be,
Doth leſſer blench at ſufferance, then I doe:
At Priams Royall Table doe I ſit;
And when faire Creſſid comes into my thoughts,
So (Traitor) then ſhe comes, when ſhe is thence.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Well:
She look’d yesternight fairer, then euer I ſaw her looke,
Or any woman else.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I was about to tell thee, when my heart,
As wedged with a ſigh, would riue in twaine,
Least Hector, or my Father ſhould perceiue me:
I haue (as when the Sunne doth light a-scorne)
Buried this ſigh, in wrinkle of a ſmile:
But ſorrow, that is couch’d in ſeeming gladneſſe,
Is like that mirth, Fate turnes to ſudden ſadneſſe.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: And her haire were not ſomewhat darker then Helens, well go too, there were no more comparison be-tweene the Women. But for my part ſhe is my Kinswo-man, I would not (as they tearme it) praise it, but I wold ſome-body had heard her talke yesterday as I did: I will not dispraise your ſister Caſſandra's wit, but—

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Oh Pandarus! I tell thee Pandarus;
When I doe tell thee, there my hopes lye drown’d:
Reply not in how many Fadomes deepe
They lye indrench’d. I tell thee, I am mad
In Creſſids loue. Thou anſwer'st ſhe is Faire,
Powr'st in the open Vlcer of my heart,
Her Eyes, her Haire, her Cheeke, her Gate, her Voice,
Handlest in thy discourse. O that her Hand
(In whose comparison, all whites are Inke)
Writing their owne reproach; to whose ſoft ſeizure,
The Cignets Downe is harsh, and ſpirit of Sense
Hard as the palme of Plough-man. This thou tel'st me;
As true thou tel'st me, when I ſay I loue her:
But ſaying thus, instead of Oyle and Balme,
Thou lai'st in euery gash that loue hath giuen me,
The Knife that made it.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I ſpeake no more then truth.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Thou do'st not ſpeake ſo much.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Faith, Ile not meddle in't: Let her be as ſhee is, if ſhe be faire, ‘tis the better for her: and ſhe be not, ſhe ha's the mends in her owne hands.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Good Pandarus: How now Pandarus?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I haue had my Labour for my trauell, ill thought on of her, and ill thought on of you: Gone betweene and betweene, but ſmall thankes for my labour.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: What art thou angry Pandarus? what with me?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Because ſhe's Kinne to me, therefore ſhee's not ſo faire as Helen, and ſhe were not kin to me, ſhe would be as faire on Friday, as Helen is on Sunday. But what care I? I care not and ſhe were a Black-a-Moore, ‘tis all one to me.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Say I ſhe is not faire?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I doe not care whether you doe or no, Shee's a Foole to ſtay behinde her Father: Let her to the Greeks, and ſo Ile tell her the next time I ſee her: for my part, Ile meddle nor make no more i'th’ matter.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Pandarus?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Not I.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Sweete Pandarus.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Pray you ſpeake no more to me, I will leaue all as I found it, and there an end.

speech.speaker: Tro.
speech.line: Peace you vngracious Clamors, peace rude ſounds,
Fooles on both ſides, Helen must needs be faire,
When with your bloud you daily paint her thus.
I cannot fight vpon this Argument:
It is too ſtaru’d a ſubiect for my Sword,
But Pandarus: O Gods! How do you plague me?
I cannot come to Creſſid but by Pandar,
And he's as teachy to be woo’d to wœ,
As ſhe is ſtubborne, chast, against all ſuite.
Tell me Apollo for thy Daphnes Loue
What Creſſid is, what Pandar, and what we:
Her bed is India, there ſhe lies, a Pearle,
Between our Ilium, and where ſhee recides
Let it be cald the wild and wandring flood,
Our ſelfe the Merchant, and this ſayling Pandar,
Our doubtfull hope, our conuoy and our Barke.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: How now Prince Troylus?
Wherefore not a field?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Because not there; this womans anſwer ſorts.
For womanish it is to be from thence:
What newes Aeneas from the field to day?

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: That Paris is returned home, and hurt.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: By whom Aeneas?

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Troylus by Menelaus.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Let Paris bleed, ‘tis but a ſcar to ſcorne.
Paris is gor’d with Menelaus horne.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Harke what good ſport is out of Towne to day.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Better at home, if would I might were may:
But to the ſport abroad, are you bound thither?

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: In all ſwift hast.

speech.speaker: Troy
speech.line: Come goe wee then togither.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Who were those went by?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: Queene Hecuba, and Hellen.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: And whether go they?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: Vp to the Easterne Tower,
Whose height commands as ſubiect all the vaile,
To ſee the battell: Hector whose pacience,
Is as a Vertue fixt, to day was mou’d:
He chides Andromache and ſtrooke his Armorer,
And like as there were husbandry in Warre
Before the Sunne rose, hee was harnest lyte,
And to the field goe's he; where euery flower
Did as a Prophet weepe what it forsaw,
In Hectors wrath.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: What was his cause of anger?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: The noise goe's thus;
There is among the Greekes,
A Lord of Troian blood, Nephew to Hector,
They call him Aiax.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Good; and what of him?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: They ſay he is a very man per ſe and ſtands alone.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: So do all men, vnleſſe they are drunke, ſicke, or haue no legges.

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: This man Lady, hath rob’d many beasts of their particular additions, he is as valiant as the Lyon, churlish as the Beare, ſlow as the Elephant: a man into whom nature hath ſo crowded humors, that his valour is crusht into folly, his folly ſauced with discretion: there is no man hath a vertue, that he hath not a glimpse of, nor a-ny man an attaint, but he carries ſome ſtaine of it. He is melancholy without cause, and merry against the haire, hee hath the ioynts of euery thing, but euery thing ſo out of ioynt, that hee is a gowtie Briareus, many hands and no vse; or purblinded Argus, all eyes and no ſight.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: But how ſhould this man that makes me ſmile, make Hector angry?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: They ſay he yesterday cop’d Hector in the bat-tell and ſtroke him downe, the disdaine & ſhame where-of, hath euer ſince kept Hector fasting and waking.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Who comes here?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: Madam your Vncle Pandarus.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Hectors a gallant man.

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: As may be in the world Lady.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: What's that? what’s that?

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Good morrow Vncle Pandarus.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Good morrow Cozen Creſſid: what do you talke of? good morrow Alexander: how do you Cozen? when were you at Illium?

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: This morning Vncle.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: What were you talking of when I came? Was Hector arm’d and gon ere yea came to Illium? Hellen was not vp? was ſhe?

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Hector was gone but Hellen was not vp?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: E'ene ſo; Hector was ſtirring early.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: That were we talking of, and of his anger.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Was he angry?

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: So he ſaies here.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: True he was ſo; I know the cause too, heele lay about him to day I can tell them that, and there's Troylus will not come farre behind him, let them take heede of Troylus; I can tell them that too.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: What is he angry too?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Who Troylus?
Troylus is the better man of the two.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Oh Iupiter; there's no comparison.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: What not betweene Troylus and Hector? do you know a man if you ſee him?

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: I, if I euer ſaw him before and knew him.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Well I ſay Troylus is Troylus.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Then you ſay as I ſay,
For I am ſure he is not Hector.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: No not Hector is not Troylus in ſome degrees.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: ‘Tis iust, to each of them he is himselfe.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Himselfe? alas poore Troylus I would he were.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: So he is.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Condition I had gone bare-foote to India.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: He is not Hector.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Himselfe? no? hee's not himselfe, would a were himselfe: well, the Gods are aboue, time must friend or end: well Troylus well, I would my heart were in her bo-dy; no, Hector is not a better man then Troylus.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Excuse me.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: He is elder.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Pardon me, pardon me.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Th’ others not come too't, you ſhall tell me ano-ther tale when th’ others come too't: Hector ſhall not haue his will this yeare.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: He ſhall not neede it if he haue his owne.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Nor his qualities.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: No matter.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Nor his beautie.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: 'Twould not become him, his own's better.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: You haue no iudgement Neece; Hellen her ſelfe ſwore th’ other day, that Troylus for a browne fauour (for ſo ‘tis I must confeſſe) not browne neither.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: No, but browne.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Faith to ſay truth, browne and not browne.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: To ſay the truth, true and not true.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: She prais’d his complexion aboue Paris.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Why Paris hath colour inough.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: So he has.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Then Troylus ſhould haue too much, if ſhe prais’d him aboue, his complexion is higher then his, he hauing colour enough, and the other higher, is too flaming a praise for a good complexion, I had as lieue Hellens gol-den tongue had commended Troylus for a copper nose.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I ſweare to you,
I thinke Hellen loues him better then Paris.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Then ſhee's a merry Greeke indeed.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Nay I am ſure ſhe does, ſhe came to him th’ other day into the compast window, and you know he has not past three or foure haires on his chinne.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Indeed a Tapsters Arithmetique may ſoone bring his particulars as therein, to a totall.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Why he is very yong, and yet will he within three pound lift as much as his brother Hector.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Is he is ſo young a man, and ſo old a lifter?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: But to prooue to you that Hellen loues him, ſhe came and puts me her white hand to his clouen chin.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Iuno haue mercy, how came it clouen?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Why, you know ‘tis dimpled, I thinke his ſmyling becomes him better then any man in all Phrigia.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Oh he ſmiles valiantly.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Doœs hee not?

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Oh yes, and 'twere a clow’d in Autumne.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Why go to then, but to proue to you that Hellen loues Troylus.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Troylus wil ſtand to thee
Proofe, if youle prooue it ſo.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Troylus? why he esteemes her no more then I e-steeme an addle egge.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: If you loue an addle egge as well as you loue an idle head, you would eate chickens i'th’ ſhell.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I cannot chuse but laugh to thinke how ſhe tick-led his chin, indeed ſhee has a maruel's white hand I must needs confeſſe.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Without the racke.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: And ſhee takes vpon her to ſpie a white haire on his chinne.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Alas poore chin? many a wart is richer.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: But there was ſuch laughing, Queene Hecuba laught that her eyes ran ore.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: With Milstones.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: And Caſſandra laught.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: But there was more temperate fire vnder the pot of her eyes: did her eyes run ore too?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: And Hector laught.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: At what was all this laughing?

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Marry at the white haire that Hellen ſpied on
Troylus chin.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: And t'had beene a greene haire, I ſhould haue laught too.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: They laught not ſo much at the haire, as at his pretty answere.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: What was his answere?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Quoth ſhee, heere's but two and fifty haires on your chinne; and one of them is white.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: This is her question.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: That's true, make no question of that, two and fiftie haires quoth hee, and one white, that white haire is my Father, and all the rest are his Sonnes. Iupiter quoth ſhe, which of these haires is Paris my husband? The for-ked one quoth he, pluckt out and giue it him: but there was ſuch laughing, and Hellen ſo blusht, and Paris ſo chaft, and all the rest ſo laught, that it past.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: So let it now,
For it has beene a great while going by.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Well Cozen,
I told you a thing yesterday, think on't.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: So I does.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Ile be ſworne ‘tis true, he will weepe you an 'twere a man borne in Aprill.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: And Ile ſpring vp in his teares, an 'twere a nettle against May.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Harke they are comming from the field, ſhal we ſtand vp here and ſee them, as they paſſe toward Illium, good Neece do, ſweet Neece Creſſida.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: At your pleasure.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Heere, heere, here's an excellent place, heere we may ſee mo’t brauely, Ile tel you them all by their names, as they paſſe by, but marke Troylus aboue the rest.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Speake not ſo low’d.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: That's Aeneas, is not that a braue man, hee's one of the flowers of Troy I can you, marke Troylus, you ſhal ſee anon.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Who's that?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: That's Antenor, he has a ſhrow’d wit I can tell you, and hee's a man good inough, hee's one o'th ſoun-dest iudgement in Troy whosœuer, and a proper man of person: when comes Troylus? Ile ſhew you Troylus anon, if hee ſee me, you ſhall ſee him nod at me.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Will he giue you the nod?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: You ſhall ſee.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: If he do, the rich ſhall haue, more.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: That's Hector, that, that looke you, that there's a fellow. Goe thy way Hector, there's a braue man Neece, O braue Hector! Looke how hee lookes? there's a coun-tenance; ist not a braue man?

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: O braue man!

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Is a not? It doœs a mans heart good, looke you what hacks are on his Helmet, looke you yonder, do you ſee? Looke you there? There's no iesting, laying on, tak't off, who will as they ſay, there be hacks.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Be those with Swords?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Swords, any thing he cares not, and the diuell come to him, it's all one, by Gods lid it doœs ones heart good. Yonder comes Paris, yonder comes Paris: looke yee yonder Neece, ist not a gallant man to, ist not? Why this is braue now: who ſaid he came hurt home to day? Hee's not hurt, why this will do Hellens heart good now, ha? Would I could ſee Troylus now, you ſhall Troy-lus anon.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Whose that?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: That's Hellenus, I maruell where Troylus is, that’s
Helenus, I thinke he went not forth to day: that’s Hel-lenus.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Can Hellenus fight Vncle?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Hellenus no: yes heele fight indifferent, well, I maruell where Troylus is; harke, do you not heare the people crie Troylus? Hellenus is a Priest.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: What ſneaking fellow comes yonder?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Where? Yonder? That's Doephobus. ‘Tis Troy-lus! Ther's a man Neece, hem? Braue Troylus the Prince of Chiualrie.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Peace, for ſhame peace.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Marke him, not him: O braue Troylus: looke well vpon him Neece, looke you how his Sword is blou-died, and his Helme more hackt then Hectors, and how he lookes, and how he goes. O admirable youth! he ne're ſaw three and twenty. Go thy way Troylus, go thy way, had I a ſister were a Grace, or a daughter a Goddeſſe, hee ſhould take his choice. O admirable man! Paris? Paris is durt to him, and I warrant, Helen to change, would giue money to boot.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Heere come more.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Aſſes, fooles, dolts, chaffe and bran, chaffe and bran; porredge after meat. I could liue and dye i'th’ eyes of Troylus. Ne're looke, ne're looke; the Eagles are gon, Crowes and Dawes, Crowes and Dawes: I had rather be ſuch a man as Troylus, then Agamemnon, and all Greece.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: There is among the Greekes Achilles, a better man then Troylus.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Achilles? a Dray-man, a Porter, a very Camell.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Well, well.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Well, well? Why haue you any discretion? haue you any eyes? Do you know what a man is? Is not birth, beauty, good ſhape, discourse, manhood, learning, gen-tleneſſe, vertue, youth, liberality, and ſo forth: the Spice, and ſalt that ſeasons a man?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: I, a minc’d man, and then to be bak’d with no Date in the pye, for then the mans dates out.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: You are ſuch another woman, one knowes not at what ward you lye.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Vpon my backe, to defend my belly; vpon my wit, to defend my wiles; vppon my ſecrecy, to defend mine honesty; my Maske, to defend my beauty, and you to defend all these: and all these wardes I lye at, at a thousand watches.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Say one of your watches.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Nay Ile watch you for that, and that’s one of the cheefest of them too: If I cannot ward what I would not haue hit, I can watch you for telling how I took the blow, vnleſſe it ſwell past hiding, and then it's past wat-ching. _

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: You are ſuch another.

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: Sir, my Lord would instantly ſpeake with you.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Where?

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: At your owne house.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Good Boy tell him I come, I doubt he bee hurt.
Fare ye well good Neece.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Adieu Vnkle.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Ile be with you Neece by and by.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: To bring Vnkle.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I, a token from Troylus.

speech.speaker: Cres
speech.line: By the ſame token, you are a Bawd. Exit Pand.
Words, vowes, gifts, teares, & loues full ſacrifice,
He offers in anothers enterprise:
But more in Troylus thousand fold I ſee,
Then in the glaſſe of Pandar's praise may be;
Yet hold I off. Women are Angels wooing,
Things won are done, ioyes ſoule lyes in the dooing:
That ſhe belou’d, knowes nought, that knowes not this;
Men prize the thing vngain’d, more then it is.
That ſhe was neuer yet, that euer knew
Loue got ſo ſweet, as when desire did ſue:
Therefore this maxime out of loue I teach;
"Atchieuement, is command; vngain’d, beseech.
That though my hearts Contents firme loue doth beare,
Nothing of that ſhall from mine eyes appeare.

scene.stagedir: Senet. Enter Agamemnon, Nestor, Vlyſſes, Diome-des, Menelaus, with others

speech.speaker: Agam.
speech.line: Princes:
What greefe hath ſet the Iaundies on your cheekes?
The ample proposition that hope makes
In all designes, begun on earth below
Fayles in the promist largeneſſe: checkes and disasters
Grow in the veines of actions highest rear’d.
As knots by the conflux of meeting ſap,
Infect the ſound Pine, and diuerts his Graine
Tortiue and erant from his course of growth.
Nor Princes, is it matter new to vs,
That we come ſhort of our ſuppose ſo farre,
That after ſeuen yeares ſiege, yet Troy walles ſtand,
Sith euery action that hath gone before,
Whereof we haue Record, Triall did draw
Bias and thwart, not answering the ayme:
And that vnbodied figure of the thought
That gaue't ſurmised ſhape. Why then (you Princes)
Do you with cheekes abash’d, behold our workes,
And thinke them ſhame, which are (indeed) nought else
But the protractiue trials of great Ioue,
To finde persistiue constancie in men?
The fineneſſe of which Mettall is not found
In Fortunes loue: for then, the Bold and Coward,
The Wise and Foole, the Artist and vn-read,
The hard and ſoft, ſeeme all affin’d, and kin.
But on the Winde and Tempest of her frowne,
Distinction with a lowd and powrefull fan,
Puffing at all, winnowes the light away;
And what hath maſſe, or matter by it ſelfe,
Lies rich in Vertue, and vnmingled.

speech.speaker: Nestor.
speech.line: With due Obseruance of thy godly ſeat,
Great Agamemnon, Nestor ſhall apply
Thy latest words.
In the reproofe of Chance,
Lies the true proofe of men: The Sea being ſmooth,
How many ſhallow bauble Boates dare ſaile
Vpon her patient brest, making their way
With those of Nobler bulke?
But let the Ruffian Boreas once enrage
The gentle Thetis, and anon behold
The ſtrong ribb’d Barke through liquid Mountaines cut,
Bounding betweene the two moyst Elements
Like Perseus Horse. Where's then the ſawcy Boate,
Whose weake vntimber’d ſides but euen now
Co-riual’d Greatneſſe? Either to harbour fled,
Or made a Toste for Neptune. Euen ſo,
Doth valours ſhew, and valours worth diuide
In ſtormes of Fortune.
For, in her ray and brightneſſe,
The Heard hath more annoyance by the Brieze
Then by the Tyger: But, when the ſplitting winde
Makes flexible the knees of knotted Oakes,
And Flies fled vnder ſhade, why then
The thing of Courage,
As rowz’d with rage, with rage doth ſympathize,
And with an accent tun’d in ſelfe-ſame key,
Retyres to chiding Fortune.

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: Agamemnon:
Thou great Commander, Nerue, and Bone of Greece,
Heart of our Numbers, ſoule, and onely ſpirit,
In whom the tempers, and the mindes of all
Should be ſhut vp: Heare what Vlyſſes ſpeakes,
Besides the applause and approbation
The which mo’t mighty for thy place and ſway,
And thou mo’t reuerend for thy ſtretcht-out life,
I giue to both your ſpeeches: which were ſuch,
As Agamemnon and the hand of Greece
Should hold vp high in Braſſe: and ſuch againe
As venerable Nestor (hatch’d in Siluer)
Should with a bond of ayre, ſtrong as the Axletree
In which the Heauens ride, knit all Greekes eares
To his experienc’d tongue: yet let it please both
(Thou Great, and Wise) to heare Vlyſſes ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Speak Prince of Ithaca, and be't of leſſe expect:
That matter needleſſe of importleſſe burthen
Diuide thy lips; then we are confident
When ranke Thersites opes his Masticke iawes,
We ſhall heare Musicke, Wit, and Oracle.

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: Troy yet vpon his basis had bene downe,
And the great Hectors ſword had lack’d a Master
But for these instances.
The ſpecialty of Rule hath beene neglected;
And looke how many Grecian Tents do ſtand
Hollow vpon this Plaine, ſo many hollow Factions.
When that the Generall is not like the Hiue,
To whom the Forragers ſhall all repaire,
What Hony is expected? Degree being vizarded,
Th’ vnworthiest ſhewes as fairely in the Maske.
The Heauens themselues, the Planets, and this Center,
Obserue degree, priority, and place,
Insisture, course, proportion, ſeason, forme,
Office, and custome, in all line of Order:
And therefore is the glorious Planet Sol
In noble eminence, enthron’d, and ſphear’d
Amid'st the other, whose med'cinable eye
Corrects the ill Aspects of Planets euill,
And postes like the Command'ment of a King,
Sans checke, to good and bad. But when the Planets
In euill mixture to disorder wander,
What Plagues, and what portents, what mutiny?
What raging of the Sea? ſhaking of Earth?
Commotion in the Windes? Frights, changes, horrors,
Diuert, and cracke, rend and deracinate
The vnity, and married calme of States
Quite from their fixure? O, when Degree is ſhak’d,
(Which is the Ladder to all high designes)
The enterprize is ſicke. How could Communities,
Degrees in Schooles, and Brother-hoods in Cities,
Peacefull Commerce from diuidable ſhores,
The primogenitiue, and due of Byrth,
Prerogatiue of Age, Crownes, Scepters, Lawrels,
(But by Degree) ſtand in Authentique place?
Take but Degree away, vn-tune that ſtring,
And hearke what Discord followes: each thing meetes
In meere oppugnancie. The bounded Waters,
Should lift their bosomes higher then the Shores,
And make a ſoppe of all this ſolid Globe:
Strength ſhould be Lord of imbecility,
And the rude Sonne ſhould ſtrike his Father dead:
Force ſhould be right, or rather, right and wrong,
(Betweene whose endleſſe iarre, Iustice recides)
Should loose her names, and ſo ſhould Iustice too.
Then euery thing includes it ſelfe in Power,
Power into Will, Will into Appetite,
And Appetite (an vniuersall Wolfe,
So doubly ſeconded with Will, and Power)
Must make perforce an vniuersall prey,
And last, eate vp himselfe.
Great Agamemnon:
This Chaos, when Degree is ſuffocate,
Followes the choaking:
And this neglection of Degree, is it
That by a pace goes backward in a purpose
It hath to climbe. The Generall's disdain’d
By him one ſtep below; he, by the next,
That next, by him beneath: ſo euery ſtep
Exampled by the first pace that is ſicke
Of his Superiour, growes to an enuious Feauer
Of pale, and bloodleſſe Emulation.
And ‘tis this Feauer that keepes Troy on foote,
Not her owne ſinewes. To end a tale of length,
Troy in our weakneſſe liues, not in her ſtrength.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: Mo’t wisely hath Vlyſſes heere discouer’d
The Feauer, whereof all our power is ſicke.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: The Nature of the ſickneſſe found (Vlyſſes)
What is the remedie?

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: The great Achilles, whom Opinion crownes,
The ſinew, and the fore-hand of our Hoste,
Hauing his eare full of his ayery Fame,
Growes dainty of his worth, and in his Tent
Lyes mocking our designes. With him, Patroclus,
Vpon a lazie Bed, the liue-long day
Breakes ſcurrill Iests,
And with ridiculous and aukward action,
(Which Slanderer, he imitation call's)
He Pageants vs. Sometime great Agamemnon,
Thy topleſſe deputation he puts on;
And like a ſtrutting Player, whose conceit
Lies in his Ham-string, and doth thinke it rich
To heare the woodden Dialogue and ſound
'Twixt his ſtretcht footing, and the Scaffolage,
Such to be pittied, and ore-rested ſeeming
He acts thy Greatneſſe in: and when he ſpeakes,
‘Tis like a Chime a mending. With tearmes vnsquar’d,
Which from the tongue of roaring Typhon dropt,
Would ſeemes Hyperboles. At this fusty ſtuffe,
The large Achilles (on his prest-bed lolling)
From his deepe Chest, laughes out a lowd applause,
Cries excellent, ‘tis Agamemnon iust.
Now play me Nestor; hum, and ſtroke thy Beard
As he, being drest to ſome Oration:
That's done, as neere as the extreamest ends
Of paralels; as like, as Vulcan and his wife,
Yet god Achilles ſtill cries excellent,
‘Tis Nestor right. Now play him (me) Patroclus,
Arming to anſwer in a night-Alarme,
And then (forsooth) the faint defects of Age
Must be the Scene of myrth, to cough, and ſpit,
And with a palsie fumbling on his Gorget,
Shake in and out the Riuet: and at this ſport
Sir Valour dies; cries, O enough Patroclus,
Or, giue me ribs of Steele, I ſhall ſplit all
In pleasure of my Spleene. And in this fashion,
All our abilities, gifts, natures, ſhapes,
Seuerals and generals of grace exact,
Atchieuments, plots, orders, preuentions,
Excitements to the field, or ſpeech for truce,
Succeſſe or loſſe, what is, or is not, ſerues
As ſtuffe for these two, to make paradoxes.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: And in the imitation of these twaine,
Who (as Vlyſſes ſayes) Opinion crownes
With an Imperiall voyce, many are infect:
Aiax is growne ſelfe-will’d, and beares his head
In ſuch a reyne, in full as proud a place
As broad Achilles, and keepes his Tent like him;
Makes factious Feasts, railes on our ſtate of Warre
Bold as an Oracle, and ſets Thersites
A ſlaue, whose Gall coines ſlanders like a Mint,
To match vs in comparisons with durt,
To weaken and discredit our exposure,
How ranke ſœuer rounded in with danger.

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: They taxe our policy, and call it Cowardice,
Count Wisedome as no member of the Warre,
Fore-stall prescience, and esteeme no acte
But that of hand: The ſtill and mentall parts,
That do contriue how many hands ſhall ſtrike
When fitneſſe call them on, and know by measure
Of their obseruant toyle, the Enemies waight,
Why this hath not a fingers dignity:
They call this Bed-worke, Mapp'ry, Cloſſet-Warre:
So that the Ramme that batters downe the wall,
For the great ſwing and rudeneſſe of his poize,
They place before his hand that made the Engine,
Or those that with the fineneſſe of their ſoules,
By Reason guide his execution.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: Let this be granted, and Achilles horse
Makes many Thetis ſonnes.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: What Trumpet? Looke Menelaus.

speech.speaker: Men
speech.line: From Troy.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: What would you 'fore our Tent?

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Is this great Agamemnons Tent, I pray you?

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Euen this.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: May one that is a Herald, and a Prince,
Do a faire meſſage to his Kingly eares?

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: With ſurety ſtronger then Achilles arme,
'Fore all the Greekish heads, which with one voyce
Call Agamemnon Head and Generall.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Faire leaue, and large ſecurity. How may
A ſtranger to those mo’t Imperial lookes,
Know them from eyes of other Mortals?

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: How?

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: I: I aske, that I might waken reuerence,
And on the cheeke be ready with a blush
Modest as morning, when ſhe coldly eyes
The youthfull Phœbus:
Which is that God in office guiding men?
Which is the high and mighty Agamemnon?

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: This Troyan ſcornes vs, or the men of Troy
Are ceremonious Courtiers.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Courtiers as free, as debonnaire; vnarm’d,
As bending Angels; that’s their Fame, in peace;
But when they would ſeeme Souldiers, they haue galles,
Good armes, ſtrong ioynts, true ſwords, & Ioues accord,
Nothing ſo full of heart. But peace Aeneas,
Peace Troyan, lay thy finger on thy lips,
The worthineſſe of praise distaines his worth:
If that he prais’d himselfe, bring the praise forth.
But what the repining enemy commends,
That breath Fame blowes, that praise ſole pure transce[n]ds.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Sir, you of Troy, call you your ſelfe Aeneas?

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: I Greeke, that is my name.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: What's your affayre I pray you?

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Sir pardon, ‘tis for Agamemnons eares.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: He heares nought priuatly
That comes from Troy.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Nor I from Troy come not to whisper him,
I bring a Trumpet to awake his eare,
To ſet his ſence on the attentiue bent,
And then to ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Speake frankely as the winde,
It is not Agamemnons ſleeping houre;
That thou ſhalt know Troyan he is awake,
He tels thee ſo himselfe.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Trumpet blow loud,
Send thy Braſſe voyce through all these lazie Tents,
And euery Greeke of mettle, let him know,
What Troy meanes fairely, ſhall be ſpoke alowd.
We haue great Agamemnon heere in Troy,
A Prince call’d Hector, Priam is his Father:
Who in this dull and long-continew’d Truce
Is rusty growne. He bad me take a Trumpet,
And to this purpose ſpeake: Kings, Princes, Lords,
If there be one among'st the fayr'st of Greece,
That holds his Honor higher then his ease,
That ſeekes his praise, more then he feares his perill,
That knowes his Valour, and knowes not his feare,
That loues his Mistris more then in confeſſion,
(With truant vowes to her owne lips he loues)
And dare avow her Beauty, and her Worth,
In other armes then hers: to him this Challenge.
Hector, in view of Troyans, and of Greekes,
Shall make it good, or do his best to do it.
He hath a Lady, wiser, fairer, truer,
Then euer Greeke did compaſſe in his armes,
And will to morrow with his Trumpet call,
Midway betweene your Tents, and walles of Troy,
To rowze a Grecian that is true in loue.
If any come, Hector ſhal honour him:
If none, hee'l ſay in Troy when he retyres,
The Grecian Dames are ſun-burnt, and not worth
The ſplinter of a Lance: Euen ſo much.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: This ſhall be told our Louers Lord Aeneas,
If none of them haue ſoule in ſuch a kinde,
We left them all at home: But we are Souldiers,
And may that Souldier a meere recreant proue,
That meanes not, hath not, or is not in loue:
If then one is, or hath, or meanes to be,
That one meets Hector; if none else, Ile be he.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: Tell him of Nestor, one that was a man
When Hectors Grandsire ſuckt: he is old now,
But if there be not in our Grecian mould,
One Noble man, that hath one ſpark of fire
To anſwer for his Loue; tell him from me,
Ile hide my Siluer beard in a Gold Beauer,
And in my Vantbrace put this wither’d brawne,
And meeting him, wil tell him, that my Lady
Was fayrer then his Grandame, and as chaste
As may be in the world: his youth in flood,
Ile pawne this truth with my three drops of blood.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Now heauens forbid ſuch ſcarsitie of youth.

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: Amen.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Faire Lord Aeneas,
Let me touch your hand:
To our Pauillion ſhal I leade you first:
Achilles ſhall haue word of this intent,
So ſhall each Lord of Greece from Tent to Tent:
Your ſelfe ſhall Feast with vs before you goe,
And finde the welcome of a Noble Fœ.

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: Nestor.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: What ſayes Vlyſſes?

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: I haue a young conception in my braine,
Be you my time to bring it to ſome ſhape.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: What is't?

speech.speaker: Vlyſſes.
speech.line: This ‘tis:
Blunt wedges riue hard knots: the ſeeded Pride
That hath to this maturity blowne vp
In ranke Achilles, must or now be cropt,
Or ſhedding breed a Nursery of like euil
To ouer-bulke vs all.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: Wel, and how?

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: This challenge that the gallant Hector ſends,
How euer it is ſpred in general name,
Relates in purpose onely to Achilles.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: The purpose is perspicuous euen as ſubstance,
Whose groſſeneſſe little charracters ſumme vp,
And in the publication make no ſtraine,
But that Achilles, were his braine as barren
As bankes of Lybia, though (Apollo knowes)
‘Tis dry enough, wil with great ſpeede of iudgement,
I, with celerity, finde Hectors purpose
Pointing on him.

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: And wake him to the anſwer, thinke you?

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: Yes, ‘tis mo’t meet; who may you else oppose
That can from Hector bring his Honor off,
If not Achilles; though't be a ſportfull Combate,
Yet in this triall, much opinion dwels.
For heere the Troyans taste our deer'st repute
With their fin'st Pallate: and trust to me Vlyſſes,
Our imputation ſhall be oddely poiz’d
In this wilde action. For the ſucceſſe
(Although particular) ſhall giue a ſcantling
Of good or bad, vnto the Generall:
And in ſuch Indexes, although ſmall prickes
To their ſubsequent Volumes, there is ſeene
The baby figure of the Gyant-maſſe
Of things to come at large. It is ſuppos’d,
He that meets Hector, iſſues from our choyse;
And choise being mutuall acte of all our ſoules,
Makes Merit her election, and doth boyle
As 'twere, from forth vs all: a man distill’d
Out of our Vertues; who miscarrying,
What heart from hence receyues the conqu'ring part
To ſteele a ſtrong opinion to themselues,
Which entertain’d, Limbes are in his instruments,
In no leſſe working, then are Swords and Bowes
Directiue by the Limbes.

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: Giue pardon to my ſpeech:
Therefore ‘tis meet Achilles meet not Hector:
Let vs (like Merchants) ſhew our fowlest Wares,
And thinke perchance they'l ſell: If not,
The luster of the better yet to ſhew,
Shall ſhew the better. Do not consent,
That euer Hector and Achilles meete:
For both our Honour, and our Shame in this,
Are dogg’d with two ſtrange Followers.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: I ſee them not with my old eies: what are they?

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: What glory our Achilles ſhares from Hector,
(Were he not proud) we all ſhould weare with him:
But he already is too insolent,
And we were better parch in Affricke Sunne,
Then in the pride and ſalt ſcorne of his eyes
Should he ſcape Hector faire. If he were foyld,
Why then we did our maine opinion crush
In taint of our best man. No, make a Lott'ry,
And by deuice let blockish Aiax draw
The ſort to fight with Hector: Among our ſelues,
Giue him allowance as the worthier man,
For that will physicke the great Myrmidon
Who broyles in lowd applause, and make him fall
His Crest, that prouder then blew Iris bends.
If the dull brainleſſe Aiax come ſafe off,
Wee'l dreſſe him vp in voyces: if he faile,
Yet go we vnder our opinion ſtill,
That we haue better men. But hit or miſſe,
Our proiects life this ſhape of ſence aſſumes,
Aiax imploy’d, pluckes downe Achilles Plumes.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: Now Vlyſſes, I begin to rellish thy aduice,
And I wil giue a taste of it forthwith
To Agamemnon, go we to him ſtraight:
Two Curres ſhal tame each other, Pride alone
Must tarre the Mastiffes on, as 'twere their bone.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Thersites?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Agamemnon, how if he had Biles (ful) all ouer generally.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Thersites?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: And those Byles did runne, ſay ſo; did not the
General run, were not that a botchy core?

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Dogge.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Then there would come ſome matter from him:
I ſee none now.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Thou Bitch-Wolfes-Sonne, canst y not heare?
Feele then.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: The plague of Greece vpon thee thou Mungrel beefe-witted Lord.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Speake then you whinid'st leauen ſpeake, I will beate thee into handsomneſſe.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I ſhal ſooner rayle thee into wit and holineſſe: but I thinke thy Horse wil ſooner con an Oration, then y learn a prayer without booke: Thou canst ſtrike, canst thou? A red Murren o'thy Iades trickes.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Toads ſtoole, learne me the Proclamation.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Doest thou thinke I haue no ſence thou ſtrik'st me thus?

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: The Proclamation.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Thou art proclaim’d a foole, I thinke.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Do not Porpentine, do not; my fingers itch.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I would thou didst itch from head to foot, and I had the ſcratching of thee, I would make thee the loth-som'st ſcab in Greece.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: I ſay the Proclamation.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Thou grumblest & railest euery houre on A-chilles, and thou art as ful of enuy at his greatnes, as Cer-berus is at Proserpina's beauty. I, that thou barkst at him.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Mistreſſe Thersites.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Thou ſhould'st ſtrike him.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Coblofe.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: He would pun thee into ſhiuers with his fist, as a Sailor breakes a bisket.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: You horson Curre.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Do, do.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Thou ſtoole for a Witch.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I, do, do, thou ſodden-witted Lord: thou hast no more braine then I haue in mine elbows: An Asinico may tutor thee. Thou ſcuruy valiant Aſſe, thou art heere but to thresh Troyans, and thou art bought and ſolde a-mong those of any wit, like a Barbarian ſlaue. If thou vse to beat me, I wil begin at thy heele, and tel what thou art by inches, thou thing of no bowels thou.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: You dogge.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: You ſcuruy Lord.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: You Curre.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Mars his Ideot: do rudenes, do Camell, do, do.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Why how now Aiax? wherefore do you this?
How now Thersites? what’s the matter man?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: You ſee him there, do you?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: I, what’s the matter.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Nay looke vpon him.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: So I do: what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Nay but regard him well.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Well, why I do ſo.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: But yet you looke not well vpon him: for who ſome euer you take him to be, he is Aiax.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: I know that foole.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I, but that foole knowes not himselfe.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: Therefore I beate thee.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Lo, lo, lo, lo, what modicums of wit he vtters: his euasions haue eares thus long. I haue bobb’d his Braine more then he has beate my bones: I will buy nine Spar-rowes for a peny, and his Piamater is not worth the ninth part of a Sparrow. This Lord (Achilles) Aiax who wears his wit in his belly, and his guttes in his head, Ile tell you what I ſay of him.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I ſay this Aiax—

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Nay good Aiax.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Has not ſo much wit.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Nay, I must hold you.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: As will ſtop the eye of Helens Needle, for whom he comes to fight.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Peace foole.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I would haue peace and quietnes, but the foole will not: he there, that he, looke you there.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: O thou damn’d Curre, I ſhall—

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Will you ſet your wit to a Fooles.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: No I warrant you, for a fooles will ſhame it.

speech.speaker: Pat.
speech.line: Good words Thersites.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What's the quarrell?

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: I bad thee vile Owle, goe learne me the tenure of the Proclamation, and he rayles vpon me.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I ſerue thee not.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: Well, go too, go too.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I ſerue heere voluntary.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Your last ſeruice was ſufferance, 'twas not vo-luntary, no man is beaten voluntary: Aiax was heere the voluntary, and you as vnder an Impreſſe.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: E'ne ſo, a great deale of your wit too lies in your ſinnewes, or else there be Liars. Hector ſhall haue a great catch, if he knocke out either of your braines, he were as good cracke a fustie nut with no kernell.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What with me to Thersites?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: There's Vlyſſes, and old Nestor, whose Wit was mouldy ere their Grandsires had nails on their tœs, yoke you like draft-Oxen, and make you plough vp the warre.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What? what?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Yes good ſooth, to Achilles, to Aiax, to—

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: I ſhall cut out your tongue.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: ‘Tis no matter, I ſhall ſpeake as much as thou afterwards.

speech.speaker: Pat.
speech.line: No more words Thersites.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I will hold my peace when Achilles Brooch bids me, ſhall I?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: There's for you Patroclus.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I will ſee you hang’d like Clotpoles ere I come any more to your Tents; I will keepe where there is wit ſtirring, and leaue the faction of fooles.

speech.speaker: Pat.
speech.line: A good riddance.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Marry this Sir is proclaim’d through al our host,
That Hector by the fift houre of the Sunne,
Will with a Trumpet, 'twixt our Tents and Troy
To morrow morning call ſome Knight to Armes,
That hath a ſtomacke, and ſuch a one that dare
Maintaine I know not what: ‘tis trash. Farewell.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: Farewell? who ſhall anſwer him?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: I know not, ‘tis put to Lottry: otherwise
He knew his man.

speech.speaker: Aiax
speech.line: O meaning you, I wil go learne more of it.

scene.stagedir: Enter Priam, Hector, Troylus, Paris and Helenus.

speech.speaker: Pri.
speech.line: After ſo many houres, liues, ſpeeches ſpent,
Thus once againe ſayes Nestor from the Greekes,
Deliuer Helen, and all damage else
(As honour, loſſe of time, trauaile, expence,
Wounds, friends, and what els deere that is consum’d
In hot digestion of this comorant Warre)
Shall be ſtroke off. Hector, what ſay you too't.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Though no man leſſer feares the Greeks then I,
As farre as touches my particular: yet dread Priam,
There is no Lady of more ſofter bowels,
More ſpungie, to ſucke in the ſense of Feare,
More ready to cry out, who knowes what followes
Then Hector is: the wound of peace is ſurety.
Surety ſecure: but modest Doubt is cal’d
The Beacon of the wise: the tent that ſearches
To'th’ bottome of the worst. Let Helen go,
Since the first ſword was drawne about this question,
Euery tythe ſoule 'mongst many thousand dismes,
Hath bin as deere as Helen: I meane of ours:
If we haue lost ſo many tenths of ours
To guard a thing not ours, nor worth to vs
(Had it our name) the valew of one ten;
What merit's in that reason which denies
The yeelding of her vp,

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Fie, fie, my Brother;
Weigh you the worth and honour of a King
(So great as our dread Father) in a Scale
Of common Ounces? Wil you with Counters ſumme
The past proportion of his infinite,
And buckle in a waste mo’t fathomleſſe,
With ſpannes and inches ſo diminutiue,
As feares and reasons? Fie for godly ſhame?

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: No maruel though you bite ſo ſharp at reasons,
You are ſo empty of them, ſhould not our Father
Beare the great ſway of his affayres with reasons,
Because your ſpeech hath none that tels him ſo.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: You are for dreames & ſlumbers brother Priest
You furre your gloues with reason: here are your reasons
You know an enemy intends you harme,
You know, a ſword imploy’d is perillous,
And reason flyes the obiect of all harme.
Who maruels then when Helenus beholds
A Grecian and his ſword, if he do ſet
The very wings of reason to his heeles:
Or like a Starre disorb’d. Nay, if we talke of Reason,
And flye like chidden Mercurie from Ioue,
Let's ſhut our gates and ſleepe: Manhood and Honor
Should haue hard hearts, wold they but fat their thoghts
With this cramm’d reason: reason and respect,
Makes Liuers pale, and lustyhood deiect.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Brother, ſhe is not worth
What ſhe doth cost the holding.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: What's aught, but as ‘tis valew’d?

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: But value dwels not in particular will,
It holds his estimate and dignitie
As well, wherein ‘tis precious of it ſelfe,
As in the prizer: ‘Tis made Idolatrie,
To make the ſeruice greater then the God,
And the will dotes that is inclineable
To what infectiously it ſelfe affects,
Without ſome image of th’ affected merit.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I take to day a Wife, and my election Is led on in the conduct of my Will; My Will enkindled by mine eyes and eares, Two traded Pylots 'twixt the dangerous ſhores Of Will, and Iudgement. How may I auoyde (Although my will distaste what it elected) The Wife I chose, there can be no euasion To blench from this, and to ſtand firme by honour. We turne not backe the Silkes vpon the Merchant When we haue ſpoyl’d them; nor the remainder Viands We do not throw in vnrespectiue ſame, Because we now are full. It was thought meete Paris ſhould do ſome vengeance on the Greekes; Your breath of full consent bellied his Sailes, The Seas and Windes (old Wranglers) tooke a Truce, And did him ſeruice; he touch’d the Ports desir’d, And for an old Aunt whom the Greekes held Captiue, He brought a Grecian Queen, whose youth & freshneſſe Wrinkles Apollœs, and makes ſtale the morning. Why keepe we her? the Grecians keepe our Aunt: Is ſhe worth keeping? Why ſhe is a Pearle, Whose price hath launch’d aboue a thousand Ships, And turn’d Crown’d Kings to Merchants. If you'l auouch, 'twas wisedome Paris went, (As you must needs, for you all cride, Go, go:) If you'l confeſſe, he brought home Noble prize, (As you must needs) for you all clapt your hands, And cride inestimable; why do you now The iſſue of your proper Wisedomes rate, And do a deed that Fortune neuer did? Begger the estimation which you priz’d, Richer then Sea and Land? O Theft mo’t base! That we haue ſtolne what we do feare to keepe. But Theeues vnworthy of a thing ſo ſtolne, That in their Country did them that disgrace, We feare to warrant in our Natiue place.

scene.stagedir: Enter Caſſandra with her haire about her eares

speech.speaker: Cas.
speech.line: Cry Troyans, cry.

speech.speaker: Priam.
speech.line: What noyse? what ſhreeke is this?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: ‘Tis our mad ſister, I do know her voyce.

speech.speaker: Cas.
speech.line: Cry Troyans.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: It is Caſſandra.

speech.speaker: Cas.
speech.line: Cry Troyans cry; lend me ten thousand eyes,
And I will fill them with Propheticke teares.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Peace ſister, peace.

speech.speaker: Cas.
speech.line: Virgins, and Boyes; mid-age & wrinkled old,
Soft infancie, that nothing can but cry,
Adde to my clamour: let vs pay betimes
A moity of that maſſe of moane to come.
Cry Troyans cry, practise your eyes with teares,
Troy must not be, nor goodly Illion ſtand,
Our fire-brand Brother Paris burnes vs all.
Cry Troyans cry, a Helen and a wœ;
Cry, cry, Troy burnes, or else let Helen goe.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Now youthfull Troylus, do not these hie ſtrains
Of diuination in our Sister, worke
Some touches of remorse? Or is your bloud
So madly hot, that no discourse of reason,
Nor feare of bad ſucceſſe in a bad cause,
Can qualifie the ſame?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Why Brother Hector,
We may not thinke the iustneſſe of each acte
Such, and no other then euent doth forme it,
Nor once deiect the courage of our mindes;
Because Caſſandra's mad, her brainsicke raptures
Cannot distaste the goodneſſe of a quarrell,
Which hath our ſeuerall Honours all engag’d
To make it gracious. For my priuate part,
I am no more touch’d, then all Priams ſonnes,
And Ioue forbid there ſhould be done among'st vs
Such things as might offend the weakest ſpleene,
To fight for, and maintaine.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Else might the world conuince of leuitie,
As well my vnder-takings as your counsels:
But I attest the gods, your full consent
Gaue wings to my propension, and cut off
All feares attending on ſo dire a proiect.
For what (alas) can these my ſingle armes?
What propugnation is in one mans valour
To ſtand the push and enmity of those
This quarrell would excite? Yet I protest,
Were I alone to paſſe the difficulties,
And had as ample power, as I haue will,
Paris ſhould ne're retract what he hath done,
Nor faint in the pursuite.

speech.speaker: Pri.
speech.line: Paris, you ſpeake
Like one be-sotted on your ſweet delights;
You haue the Hony ſtill, but these the Gall,
So to be valiant, is no praise at all.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Sir, I propose not meerely to my ſelfe,
The pleasures ſuch a beauty brings with it:
But I would haue the ſoyle of her faire Rape
Wip’d off in honourable keeping her.
What Treason were it to the ransack’d Queene,
Disgrace to your great worths, and ſhame to me,
Now to deliuer her poſſeſſion vp
On termes of base compulsion? Can it be,
That ſo degenerate a ſtraine as this,
Should once ſet footing in your generous bosomes?
There's not the meanest ſpirit on our partie,
Without a heart to dare, or ſword to draw,
When Helen is defended: nor none ſo Noble,
Whose life were ill bestow’d, or death vnfam’d,
Where Helen is the ſubiect. Then (I ſay)
Well may we fight for her, whom we know well,
The worlds large ſpaces cannot paralell.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Paris and Troylus, you haue both ſaid well:
And on the cause and question now in hand,
Haue gloz’d, but ſuperficially; not much
Vnlike young men, whom Aristotle thought
Vnfit to heare Morall Philosophie.
The Reasons you alledge, do more conduce
To the hot paſſion of distemp'red blood,
Then to make vp a free determination
'Twixt right and wrong: For pleasure, and reuenge,
Haue eares more deafe then Adders, to the voyce
Of any true decision. Nature craues
All dues be rendred to their Owners: now
What neerer debt in all humanity,
Then Wife is to the Husband? If this law
Of Nature be corrupted through affection,
And that great mindes of partiall indulgence,
To their benummed wills resist the ſame,
There is a Law in each well-ordred Nation,
To curbe those raging appetites that are
Mo’t disobedient and refracturie.
If Helen then be wife to Sparta's King
(As it is knowne ſhe is) these Morall Lawes
Of Nature, and of Nation, ſpeake alowd
To haue her backe return’d. Thus to persist
In doing wrong, extenuates not wrong,
But makes it much more heauie. Hectors opinion
Is this in way of truth: yet nere the leſſe,
My ſpritely brethren, I propend to you
In resolution to keepe Helen ſtill;
For ‘tis a cause that hath no meane dependance,
Vpon our ioynt and ſeuerall dignities.

speech.speaker: Tro.
speech.line: Why? there you toucht the life of our designe:
Were it not glory that we more affected,
Then the performance of our heauing ſpleenes,
I would not wish a drop of Troian blood,
Spent more in her defence. But worthy Hector,
She is a theame of honour and renowne,
A ſpurre to valiant and magnanimous deeds,
Whose present courage may beate downe our fœs,
And fame in time to come canonize vs.
For I presume braue Hector would not loose
So rich aduantage of a promis’d glory,
As ſmiles vpon the fore-head of this action,
For the wide worlds reuenew.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: I am yours, You valiant off-spring of great Priamus, I haue a roisting challenge ſent among'st The dull and factious nobles of the Greekes, Will ſtrike amazement to their drowsie ſpirits, I was aduertiz’d, their Great generall ſlept, Whil'st emulation in the armie crept: This I presume will wake him. Exeunt. Enter Thersites ſolus. How now Thersites? what lost in the Labyrinth of thy furie? ſhall the Elephant Aiax carry it thus? he beates me, and I raile at him: O worthy ſatisfaction, would it were otherwise: that I could beate him, whil'st he rail’d at me: Sfoote, Ile learne to coniure and raise Diuels, but Ile ſee ſome iſſue of my ſpitefull execrations. Then ther's Achilles, a rare Enginer. If Troy be not taken till these two vndermine it, the wals will ſtand till they fall of them-selues. O thou great thunder-darter of Olympus, forget that thou art Ioue the King of gods: and Mercury, loose all the Serpentine craft of thy Caduceus, if thou take not that little little leſſe then little wit from them that they haue, which ſhort-arm’d ignorance it ſelfe knowes, is ſo abundant ſcarse, it will not in circumuention deliuer a Flye from a Spider, without drawing the maſſie Irons and cutting the web: after this, the vengeance on the whole Camp, or rather the bone-ach, for that me thinkes is the curse dependant on those that warre for a placket. I haue ſaid my prayers and diuell, enuie, ſay Amen: What ho? my Lord Achilles?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Who's there? Thersites. Good Thersites come in and raile.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: If I could haue remembred a guilt counterfeit, thou would'st not haue ſlipt out of my contemplation, but it is no matter, thy ſelfe vpon thy ſelfe. The common curse of mankinde, follie and ignorance be thine in great reuenew; heauen bleſſe thee from a Tutor, and Discipline come not neere thee. Let thy bloud be thy direction till thy death, then if ſhe that laies thee out ſayes thou art a faire coarse, Ile be ſworne and ſworne vpon't ſhe neuer ſhrowded any but Lazars, Amen. Wher's Achilles?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: What art thou deuout? wast thou in a prayer?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I, the heauens heare me.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Who's there?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Thersites, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Where, where, art thou come? why my cheese, my digestion, why hast thou not ſeru’d thy ſelfe into my Table, ſo many meales? Come, what’s Agamemnon?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Thy Commander Achilles, then tell me Patro-clus, what’s Achilles?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Thy Lord Thersites: then tell me I pray thee, what’s thy ſelfe?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Thy knower Patroclus: then tell me Patroclus, what art thou?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Thou maist tell that know'st.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: O tell, tell.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Ile declin the whole question: Agamemnon com-mands Achilles, Achilles is my Lord, I am Patroclus know-er, and Patroclus is a foole.

speech.speaker: Patro.
speech.line: You rascall.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Peace foole, I haue not done.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: He is a priuiledg’d man, proceede Thersites.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Agamemnon is a foole, Achilles is a foole, Ther-sites is a foole, and as aforesaid, Patroclus is a foole.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Deriue this? come?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Agamemnon is a foole to offer to command A-chilles, Achilles is a foole to be commanded of Agamemnon, Thersites is a foole to ſerue ſuch a foole: and Patroclus is a foole positiue.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Why am I a foole?

scene.stagedir: Enter Agamemnon, Vliſſes, Nestor, Diomedes, Aiax, and Chalcas

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Make that demand to the Creator, it ſuffises me thou art. Looke you, who comes here?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Patroclus, Ile ſpeake with no body: come in with me Thersites.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Here is ſuch patcherie, ſuch iugling, and ſuch knauerie: all the argument is a Cuckold and a Whore, a good quarrel to draw emulations, factions, and bleede to death vpon: Now the dry Suppeago on the Subiect, and Warre and Lecherie confound all.

speech.speaker: Agam.
speech.line: Where is Achilles?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Within his Tent, but ill dispos’d my Lord.

speech.speaker: Agam.
speech.line: Let it be knowne to him that we are here:
He ſent our Meſſengers, and we lay by
Our appertainments, visiting of him:
Let him be told of, ſo perchance he thinke
We dare not moue the question of our place,
Or know not what we are.

speech.speaker: Pat.
speech.line: I ſhall ſo ſay to him.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: We ſaw him at the opening of his Tent, he is not ſicke.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Yes, Lyon ſicke, ſicke of proud heart; you may call it Melancholly if will fauour the man, but by my head, it is pride; but why, why, let him ſhow vs the cause? A word my Lord.

speech.speaker: Nes.
speech.line: What moues Aiax thus to bay at him?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Achilles hath inueigled his Foole from him.

speech.speaker: Nes.
speech.line: Who, Thersites?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: He.

speech.speaker: Nes.
speech.line: Then will Aiax lacke matter, if he haue lost his
Argument.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: No, you ſee he is his argument that has his argu-ment
Achilles.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: All the better, their fraction is more our wish then their faction; but it was a ſtrong counsell that a Foole could disunite.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: The amitie that wisedome knits, not folly may easily vntie. Enter Patroclus. Here comes Patroclus.

speech.speaker: Nes.
speech.line: No Achilles with him?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: The Elephant hath ioynts, but none for curtesie:
His legge are legs for neceſſitie, not for flight.

speech.speaker: Patro.
speech.line: Achilles bids me ſay he is much ſorry:
If any thing more then your ſport and pleasure,
Did moue your greatneſſe, and this noble State,
To call vpon him; he hopes it is no other,
But for your health, and your digestion ſake;
An after Dinners breath.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Heare you Patroclus:
We are too well acquainted with these answers:
But his euasion winged thus ſwift with ſcorne,
Cannot but flye our apprehensions.
Much attribute he hath, and much the reason,
Why we ascribe it to him, yet all his vertues,
Not vertuously of his owne part beheld,
Doe in our eyes, begin to loose their gloſſe;
Yea, and like faire Fruit in an vnholdsome dish,
Are like to rot vntasted: goe and tell him,
We came to ſpeake with him; and you ſhall not ſinne,
If you doe ſay, we thinke him ouer proud,
And vnder honeſt; in ſelfe-aſſumption greater
Then in the note of iudgement: & worthier then himselfe
Here tends the ſauage ſtrangeneſſe he puts on,
Disguise the holy ſtrength of their command:
And vnder write in an obseruing kinde
His humorous predominance, yea watch
His pettish lines, his ebs, his flowes, as if
The paſſage and whole carriage of this action
Rode on his tyde. Goe tell him this, and adde,
That if he ouerhold his price ſo much,
Weele none of him; but let him, like an Engin
Not portable, lye vnder this report.
Bring action hither, this cannot goe to warre:
A ſtirring Dwarfe, we doe allowance giue,
Before a ſleeping Gyant: tell him ſo.

speech.speaker: Pat.
speech.line: I ſhall, and bring his anſwer presently.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: In ſecond voyce weele not be ſatisfied,
We come to ſpeake with him, Vliſſes enter you.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: What is he more then another?

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: No more then what he thinkes he is.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Is he ſo much, doe you not thinke, he thinkes himselfe a better man then I am?

speech.speaker: Ag.
speech.line: No question.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: Will you ſubscribe his thought, and ſay he is?

speech.speaker: Ag.
speech.line: No, Noble Aiax, you are as ſtrong, as valiant, as wise, no leſſe noble, much more gentle, and altogether more tractable.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: Why ſhould a man be proud? How doth pride grow? I know not what it is.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Your minde is the cleerer Aiax, and your vertues the fairer; he that is proud, eates vp himselfe; Pride is his owne Glaſſe, his owne trumpet, his owne Chronicle, and what euer praises it ſelfe but in the deede, deuoures the deede in the praise.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: I do hate a proud man, as I hate the ingendring of Toades.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: Yet he loues himselfe: is't not ſtrange?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Achilles will not to the field to morrow.

speech.speaker: Ag.
speech.line: What's his excuse?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: He doth relye on none,
But carries on the ſtreame of his dispose,
Without oberuance or respect of any,
In will peculiar, and in ſelfe admiſſion.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Why, will he not vpon our faire request,
Vntent his person, and ſhare the ayre with vs?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Things ſmall as nothing, for requests ſake onely
He makes important; poſſest he is with greatneſſe,
And ſpeakes not to himselfe, but with a pride
That quarrels at ſelfe-breath. Imagin’d wroth
Holds in his bloud ſuch ſwolne and hot discourse,
That twixt his mentall and his actiue parts,
Kingdom’d Achilles in commotion rages,
And batters gainst it ſelfe; what ſhould I ſay?
He is ſo plaguy proud, that the death tokens of it,
Cry no recouery.

speech.speaker: Ag.
speech.line: Let Aiax goe to him.
Deare Lord, goe you and greete him in his Tent;
‘Tis ſaid he holds you well, and will be led
At your request a little from himselfe.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: O Agamemnon, let it not be ſo.
Weele consecrate the ſteps that Aiax makes,
When they goe from Achilles; ſhall the proud Lord,
That bastes his arrogance with his owne ſeame,
And neuer ſuffers matter of the world,
Enter his thoughts: ſaue ſuch as doe reuolue
And ruminate himselfe. Shall he be worshipt,
Of that we hold an Idoll, more then hee?
No, this thrice worthy and right valiant Lord,
Must not ſo ſtaule his Palme, nobly acquir’d,
Nor by my will aſſubiugate his merit,
As amply titled as Achilles is: by going to Achilles,
That were to enlard his fat already, pride,
And adde more Coles to Cancer, when he burnes
With entertaining great Hiperion.
This L[ord]. goe to him? Iupiter forbid,
And ſay in thunder, Achilles goe to him.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: O this is well, he rubs the veine of him.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: And how his ſilence drinkes vp this applause.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: If I goe to him, with my armed fist, Ile pash him ore the face.

speech.speaker: Ag.
speech.line: O no, you ſhall not goe.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: And a be proud with me, ile phese his pride: let me goe to him.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Not for the worth that hangs vpon our quarrel.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: A paultry insolent fellow.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: How he describes himselfe.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Can he not be ſociable?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: The Rauen chides blackneſſse.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: He let his humours bloud.

speech.speaker: Ag.
speech.line: He will be the Physitian that ſhould be the pa-tient.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: And all men were a my minde.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Wit would be out of fashion.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: A ſhould not beare it ſo, a ſhould eate Swords first: ſhall pride carry it?

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: And 'twould, you'ld carry halfe.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: A would haue ten ſhares.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: I will knede him, Ile make him ſupple, hee's not yet through warme.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: Force him with praises, poure in, poure in: his am-bition is dry.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: My L[ord]. you feede too much on this dislike.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: Our noble Generall, doe not doe ſo.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: You must prepare to fight without Achilles.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Why, ‘tis this naming of him doth him harme.
Here is a man, but ‘tis before his face,
I will be ſilent.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: Wherefore ſhould you ſo?
He is not emulous, as Achilles is.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: 'Know the whole world, he is as valiant.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: A horson dog, that ſhal palter thus with vs, would he were a Troian.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: What a vice were it in Aiax now—

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: If he were proud.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Or couetous of praise.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: I, or ſurley borne.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Or ſtrange, or ſelfe affected.

speech.speaker: Vl.
speech.line: Thank the heauens L[ord]. thou art of ſweet composure;
Praise him that got thee, ſhe that gaue thee ſucke:
Fame be thy Tutor, and thy parts of nature
Thrice fam’d beyond, beyond all erudition;
But he that disciplin’d thy armes to fight,
Let Mars deuide Eternity in twaine,
And giue him halfe, and for thy vigour,
Bull-bearing Milo: his addition yeelde
To ſinnowie Aiax: I will not praise thy wisdome,
Which like a bourne, a pale, a ſhore confines
Thy ſpacious and dilated parts; here's Nestor
Instructed by the Antiquary times:
He must, he is, he cannot but be wise.
But pardon Father Nestor, were your dayes
As greene as Aiax, and your braine ſo temper’d,
You ſhould not haue the eminence of him,
But be as Aiax.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Shall I call you Father?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: I my good Sonne.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Be rul’d by him Lord Aiax.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: There is no tarrying here, the Hart Achilles
Keepes thicket: please it our Generall,
To call together all his ſtate of warre,
Fresh Kings are come to Troy; to morrow
We must with all our maine of power ſtand fast:
And here's a Lord, come Knights from East to West,
And cull their flowre, Aiax ſhall cope the best.

speech.speaker: Ag.
speech.line: Goe we to Counsaile, let Achilles ſleepe; Light Botes may ſaile ſwift, though greater bulkes draw deepe.

scene.stagedir: Musicke ſounds within. Enter Pandarus and a Seruant.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Friend, you, pray you a word: Doe not you fol-low the yong Lord Paris?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: I ſir, when he goes before me.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: You depend vpon him I meane?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Sir, I doe depend vpon the Lord.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: You depend vpon a noble Gentleman: I must needes praise him.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: The Lord be praised.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: You know me, doe you not?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Faith ſir, ſuperficially.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Friend know me better, I am the Lord Pandarus.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: I hope I ſhall know your honour better.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: I doe desire it.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: You are in the ſtate of Grace?

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Grace, not ſo friend, honor and Lordship are my title: What Musique is this?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: I doe but partly know ſir: it is Musicke in parts.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Know you the Musitians.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Wholly ſir.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Who play they to?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: To the hearers ſir.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: At whose pleasure friend?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: At mine ſir, and theirs that loue Musicke.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Command, I meane friend.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Who ſhall I command ſir?

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Friend, we vnderstand not one another: I am too courtly, and thou art too cunning. At whose request doe these men play?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: That's too't indeede ſir: marry ſir, at the request of Paris my L[ord]. who's there in person; with him the mor-tall Venus, the heart bloud of beauty, loues inuisible ſoule.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Who? my Cosin Creſſida.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: No ſir, Helen, could you not finde out that by her attributes?

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: It ſhould ſeeme fellow, that thou hast not ſeen the Lady Creſſida. I come to ſpeake with Paris from the Prince Troylus: I will make a complementall aſſault vpon him, for my busineſſe ſeethes.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Sodden busineſſe, there's a ſtewed phrase indeede.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Faire be to you my Lord, and to all this faire com-pany: faire desires in all faire measure fairely guide them, especially to you faire Queene, faire thoughts be your faire pillow.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: Deere L[ord]. you are full of faire words.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: You ſpeake your faire pleasure ſweete Queene: faire Prince, here is good broken Musicke.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: You haue broke it cozen: and by my life you ſhall make it whole againe, you ſhall peece it out with a peece of your performance. Nel, he is full of harmony.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Truely Lady no.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: O ſir.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Rude in ſooth, in good ſooth very rude.

speech.speaker: Paris.
speech.line: Well ſaid my Lord: well, you ſay ſo in fits.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I haue busineſſe to my Lord, deere Queene: my
Lord will you vouchsafe me a word.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: Nay, this ſhall not hedge vs out, weele heare you ſing certainely.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Well ſweete Queene you are pleasant with me, but, marry thus my Lord, my deere Lord, and mo’t estee-med friend your brother Troylus.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: My Lord Pandarus, hony ſweete Lord.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Go too ſweete Queene, goe to.
Commends himselfe mo’t affectionately to you.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: You ſhall not bob vs out of our melody:
If you doe, our melancholly vpon your head.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Sweete Queene, ſweete Queene, that’s a ſweete
Queene Ifaith—

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: And to make a ſweet Lady ſad, is a ſower offence.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Nay, that ſhall not ſerue your turne, that ſhall it not in truth la. Nay, I care not for ſuch words, no, no. And my Lord he desires you, that if the King call for him at Supper, you will make his excuse.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: My Lord Pandarus?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: What ſaies my ſweete Queene, my very, very ſweete Queene?

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: What exploit's in hand, where ſups he to night?

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: Nay but my Lord?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: What ſaies my ſweete Queene? my cozen will fall out with you.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: You must not know where he ſups.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: With my disposer Creſſida.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: No, no; no ſuch matter, you are wide, come your disposer is ſicke.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Well, Ile make excuse.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I good my Lord: why ſhould you ſay Creſſida? no, your poore disposer's ſicke.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: I ſpie.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: You ſpie, what doe you ſpie: come, giue me an
Instrument now ſweete Queene.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: Why this is kindely done?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: My Neece is horrible in loue with a thing you haue ſweete Queene.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: She ſhall haue it my Lord, if it be not my Lord
Paris.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Hee? no, ſheele none of him, they two are twaine.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: Falling in after falling out, may make them three.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Come, come, Ile heare no more of this, Ile ſing you a ſong now.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: I, I, prethee now: by my troth ſweet Lord thou hast a fine fore-head.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I you may, you may.

speech.speaker: Hel.
