speech.line: Let thy ſong be loue: this loue will vndœ vs al.
Oh Cupid, Cupid, Cupid.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Loue? I that it ſhall yfaith.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: I, good now loue, loue, no thing but loue.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: In good troth it begins ſo.
Loue, loue, nothing but loue, ſtill more:
For O loues Bow,
Shootes Bucke and Doe:
The Shaft confounds not that it wounds,
But tickles ſtill the ſore:
These Louers cry, oh ho they dye;
Yet that which ſeemes the wound to kill,
Doth turne oh ho, to ha ha he:
So dying loue liues ſtill,
Oh ho a while, but ha ha ha,
O he grones out for ha ha ha — hey ho.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: In loue yfaith to the very tip of the nose.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: He eates nothing but doues loue, and that breeds hot bloud, and hot bloud begets hot thoughts, and hot thoughts beget hot deedes, and hot deedes is loue.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Is this the generation of loue? Hot bloud, hot thoughts, and hot deedes, why they are Vipers, is Loue a generation of Vipers? Sweete Lord, whose a field to day?

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Hector, Deiphœbus, Helenus, Anthenor, and all the gallantry of Troy. I would faine haue arm’d to day, but my Nell would not haue it ſo. How chance my brother Troylus went not?

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: He hangs the lippe at ſomething; you know all
Lord Pandarus?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Not I hony ſweete Queene: I long to heare how they ſped to day: Youle remember your brothers excuse?

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: To a hayre.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Farewell ſweete Queene.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: Commend me to your Neece.

speech.speaker: Pan
speech.line: I will ſweete Queene. Sound a retreat.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: They're come from fielde: let vs to Priams Hall
To greete the Warriers. Sweet Hellen, I must wœ you,
To helpe vnarme our Hector: his ſtubborne Buckles,
With these your white enchanting fingers toucht,
Shall more obey then to the edge of Steele,
Or force of Greekish ſinewes: you ſhall doe more
Then all the Iland Kings, disarme great Hector.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: 'Twill make vs proud to be his ſeruant Paris:
Yea what he ſhall receiue of vs in duetie,
Giues vs more palme in beautie then we haue:
Yea ouershines our ſelfe.
Sweete aboue thought I loue thee.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: How now, where's thy Maister, at my Couzen
Creſſidas?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: No ſir, he ſtayes for you to conduct him thither.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: O here he comes: How now, how now?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Sirra walke off.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Haue you ſeene my Cousin?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: No Pandarus: I ſtalke about her doore
Like a ſtrange ſoule vpon the Stigian bankes
Staying for waftage. O be thou my Charon,
And giue me ſwift transportance to those fields,
Where I may wallow in the Lilly beds
Propos’d for the deseruer. O gentle Pandarus,
From Cupids ſhoulder plucke his painted wings,
And flye with me to Creſſid.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Walke here ith 'Orchard, Ile bring her ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I am giddy; expectation whirles me round,
Th’ imaginary relish is ſo ſweete,
That it inchants my ſence: what will it be
When that the watry pallats taste indeede
Loues thrice reputed Nectar? Death I feare me
Sounding distruction, or ſome ioy too fine,
Too ſubtile, potent, and too ſharpe in ſweetneſſe,
For the capacitie of my ruder powers;
I feare it much, and I doe feare besides,
That I ſhall loose distinction in my ioyes,
As doth a battaile, when they charge on heapes
The enemy flying. Enter Pandarus.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Shee's making her ready, ſheele come ſtraight; you must be witty now, ſhe does ſo blush, & fetches her winde ſo ſhort, as if ſhe were fraid with a ſprite: Ile fetch her; it is the prettiest villaine, ſhe fetches her breath ſo ſhort as a new tane Sparrow.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Euen ſuch a paſſion doth imbrace my bosome:
My heart beates thicker then a feauorous pulse,
And all my powers doe their bestowing loose,
Like vaſſalage at vnawares encountring
The eye of Maiestie.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Come, come, what neede you blush? Shames a babie; here ſhe is now, ſweare the oathes now to her, that you haue ſworne to me. What are you gone a-gaine, you must be watcht ere you be made tame, must you? come your wayes, come your wayes, and you draw backward weele put you i'th fils: why doe you not ſpeak to her? Come draw this curtaine, & let's ſee your picture. Alaſſe the day, how loath you are to offend day light? and 'twere darke you'ld close ſooner: So, ſo, rub on, and kiſſe the mistreſſe; how now, a kiſſe in fee-farme? build there Carpenter, the ayre is ſweete. Nay, you ſhall fight your hearts out ere I part you. The Faulcon, as the Tercell, for all the Ducks ith Riuer: go too, go too.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: You haue bereft me of all words Lady.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Words pay no debts; giue her deedes: but ſheele bereaue you o'th’ deeds too, if ſhee call your actiuity in question: what billing againe? here's in witneſſe where-of the Parties interchangeably. Come in, come in, Ile go get a fire?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Will you walke in my Lord?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: O Creſſida, how often haue I wisht me thus?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Wisht my Lord? the gods grant? O my Lord.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: What ſhould they grant? what makes this pret-ty abruption: what too curious dreg espies my ſweete La-dy in the fountaine of our loue?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: More dregs then water, if my teares haue eyes.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Feares make diuels of Cherubins, they neuer ſee truely.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Blinde feare, that ſeeing reason leads, findes ſafe footing, then blinde reason, ſtumbling without feare: to feare the worst, oft cures the worse.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Oh let my Lady apprehend no feare,
In all Cupids Pageant there is presented no monster.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Not nothing monstrous neither?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Nothing but our vndertakings, when we vowe to weepe ſeas, liue in fire, eate rockes, tame Tygers; think-ing it harder for our Mistreſſe to deuise imposition inough, then for vs to vndergœ any difficultie imposed. This is the monstruositie in loue Lady, that the will is in-finite, and the execution confin’d; that the desire is bound-leſſe, and the act a ſlaue to limit.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: They ſay all Louers ſweare more performance then they are able, and yet reserue an ability that they neuer performe: vowing more then the perfection of ten; and discharging leſſe then the tenth part of one. They that haue the voyce of Lyons, and the act of Hares: are they not Monsters?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Are there ſuch? ſuch are not we: Praise vs as we are tasted, allow vs as we proue: our head ſhall goe bare till merit crowne it: no perfection in reuersion ſhall haue a praise in present: wee will not name desert before his birth, and being borne his addition ſhall be humble: few words to faire faith. Troylus ſhall be ſuch to Creſſid, as what enuie can ſay worst, ſhall be a mocke for his truth; and what truth can ſpeake truest, not truer then Troy-lus. _

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Will you walke in my Lord?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: What blushing ſtill? haue you not done talking yet?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Wel! Vnckle, what folly I commit, I dedicate to you.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I thanke you for that: if my Lord get a Boy of you, youle giue him me: be true to my Lord, if he flinch, chide me for it.

speech.speaker: Tro.
speech.line: You know now your hostages: your Vnckles word and my firme faith.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Nay, Ile giue my word for her too: our kindred though they be long ere they are woœd, they are con-stant being wonne: they are Burres I can tell you, they'le ſticke where they are throwne.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Boldneſſe comes to mee now, and brings mee heart: Prince Troylus, I haue lou’d you night and day, for many weary moneths.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Why was my Creſſid then ſo hard to win?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Hard to ſeeme won: but I was won my Lord
With the first glance; that euer pardon me,
If I confeſſe much you will play the tyrant:
I loue you now, but not till now ſo much
But I might maister it; infaith I lye:
My thoughts were like vnbrideled children grow
Too head-strong for their mother: ſee we fooles,
Why haue I blab’d: who ſhall be true to vs
When we are ſo vnsecret to our ſelues?
But though I lou’d you well, I wœd you not,
And yet good faith I wisht my ſelfe a man;
Or that we women had mens priuiledge
Of ſpeaking first. Sweet, bid me hold my tongue,
For in this rapture I ſhall ſurely ſpeake
The thing I ſhall repent: ſee, ſee, your ſilence
Comming in dumbneſſe, from my weakneſſe drawes
My ſoule of counsell from me. Stop my mouth.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: And ſhall, albeit ſweete Musicke iſſues thence.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Pretty yfaith.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: My Lord, I doe beseech you pardon me,
'Twas not my purpose thus to beg a kiſſe:
I am asham’d; O Heauens, what haue I done!
For this time will I take my leaue my Lord.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Your leaue ſweete Creſſid?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Leaue: and you take leaue till to morrow mor-ning.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Pray you content you.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: What offends you Lady?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Sir, mine owne company.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: You cannot ſhun your ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Let me goe and try:
I haue a kinde of ſelfe recides with you:
But an vnkinde ſelfe, that it ſelfe will leaue,
To be anothers foole. Where is my wit?
I would be gone: I ſpeake I know not what.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Well know they what they ſpeake, that ſpeakes ſo wisely.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Perchance my Lord, I ſhew more craft then loue,
And fell ſo roundly to a large confeſſion,
To Angle for your thoughts: but you are wise,
Or else you loue not: for to be wise and loue,
Exceedes mans might, that dwels with gods aboue.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: O that I thought it could be in a woman:
As if it can, I will presume in you,
To feede for aye her lampe and flames of loue.
To keepe her constancie in plight and youth,
Out-liuing beauties outward, with a minde
That doth renew ſwifter then blood decaies:
Or that perswasion could but thus conuince me,
That my integritie and truth to you,
Might be affronted with the match and waight
Of ſuch a winnowed puritie in loue:
How were I then vp-lifted! but alas,
I am as true, as truths ſimplicitie,
And ſimpler then the infancie of truth.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: In that Ile warre with you.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: O vertuous fight,
When right with right wars who ſhall be mo’t right:
True ſwaines in loue, ſhall in the world to come
Approue their truths by Troylus, when their times,
Full of protest, of oath and big compare;
Wants ſimiles, truth tir’d with iteration,
As true as ſteele, as plantage to the Moone:
As Sunne to day: as Turtle to her mate:
As Iron to Adamant: as Earth to th 'Center:
Yet after all comparisons of truth,
(As truths authenticke author to be cited)
As true as Troylus, ſhall crowne vp the Verse,
And ſanctifie the numbers.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Prophet may you be:
If I be false, or ſwerue a haire from truth,
When time is old and hath forgot it ſelfe:
When water drops haue worne the Stones of Troy;
And blinde obliuion ſwallow’d Cities vp;
And mightie States characterleſſe are grated
To dustie nothing; yet let memory,
From false to false, among false Maids in loue,
Vpbraid my falsehood, when they'aue ſaid as false,
As Aire, as Water, as Winde, as ſandie earth;
As Foxe to Lambe; as Wolfe to Heifers Calfe;
Pard to the Hinde, or Stepdame to her Sonne;
Yea, let them ſay, to ſticke the heart of falsehood,
As false as Creſſid.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Go too, a bargaine made: ſeale it, ſeale it, Ile be the witneſſe here I hold your hand: here my Cousins, if euer you proue false one to another, ſince I haue taken ſuch paines to bring you together, let all pittifull goers betweene be cal’d to the worlds end after my name: call them all Panders; let all constant men be Troyluſſes, all false women Creſſids, and all brokers betweene, Panders: ſay, Amen.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Amen.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Amen.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Amen. Whereupon I will ſhew you a Chamber, which bed, be-cause it ſhall not ſpeake of your prettie encounters, preſſe it to death: away. And Cupid grant all tong-tide Maidens heere, Bed, Chamber, and Pander, to prouide this geere. Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Enter Vlyſſes, Diomedes, Nestor, Agamemnon, Menelaus and Chalcas. Florish

speech.speaker: Cal.
speech.line: Now Princes for the ſeruice I haue done you,
Th’ aduantage of the time promps me aloud,
To call for recompence: appeare it to your minde,
That through the ſight I beare in things to loue,
I haue abandon’d Troy, left my poſſeſſion,
Incur’d a Traitors name, expos’d my ſelfe,
From certaine and poſſest conueniences,
To doubtfull fortunes, ſequestring from me all
That time, acquaintance, custome and condition,
Made tame, and mo’t familiar to my nature:
And here to doe you ſeruice am become,
As new into the world, ſtrange, vnacquainted.
I doe beseech you, as in way of taste,
To giue me now a little benefit:
Out of those many registred in promise,
Which you ſay, liue to come in my behalfe.

speech.speaker: Agam.
speech.line: What would'st thou of vs Troian? make demand?

speech.speaker: Cal.
speech.line: You haue a Troian prisoner, cal’d Anthenor,
Yesterday tooke: Troy holds him very deere.
Oft haue you (often haue you, thankes therefore)
Desir’d my Creſſid in right great exchange.
Whom Troy hath ſtill deni’d: but this Anthenor,
I know is ſuch a wrest in their affaires;
That their negotiations all must ſlacke,
Wanting his mannage: and they will almost,
Giue vs a Prince of blood, a Sonne of Priam,
In change of him. Let him be ſent great Princes,
And he ſhall buy my Daughter: and her presence,
Shall quite ſtrike off all ſeruice I haue done,
In mo’t accepted paine.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Let Diomedes beare him,
And bring vs Creſſid hither: Calcas ſhall haue
What he requests of vs: good Diomed
Furnish you fairely for this enterchange;
Withall bring word, if Hector will to morrow
Be anſwer’d in his challenge. Aiax is ready.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: This ſhall I vndertake, and ‘tis a burthen
Which I am proud to beare.

scene.stagedir: Enter Achilles and Patroclus in their Tent.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Achilles ſtands i'th entrance of his Tent;
Please it our Generall to paſſe ſtrangely by him,
As if he were forgot: and Princes all,
Lay negligent and loose regard vpon him;
I will come last, ‘tis like heele question me,
Why ſuch vnplausiue eyes are bent? why turn’d on him?
If ſo, I haue derision medicinable,
To vse betweene your ſtrangeneſſe and his pride,
Which his owne will ſhall haue desire to drinke;
It may doe good, pride hath no other glaſſe
To ſhow it ſelfe, but pride: for ſupple knees,
Feede arrogance, and are the proud mans fees.

speech.speaker: Agam.
speech.line: Weele execute your purpose, and put on
A forme of ſtrangeneſſe as we paſſe along,
So doe each Lord, and either greete him not,
Or else disdainfully, which ſhall ſhake him more,
Then if not lookt on. I will lead the way.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What comes the Generall to ſpeake with me?
You know my minde, Ile fight no more 'gainst Troy.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: What ſaies Achilles, would he ought with vs?

speech.speaker: Nes.
speech.line: Would you my Lord ought with the Generall?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Nes.
speech.line: Nothing my Lord.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: The better.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Good day, good day.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: How doe you? how doe you?

speech.speaker: Achi.
speech.line: What, do's the Cuckold ſcorne me?

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: How now Patroclus?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Good morrow Aiax?

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: Ha.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Good morrow.

speech.speaker: Aiax
speech.line: I, and good next day too.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What meane these fellowes? know they not
Achilles?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: They paſſe by ſtrangely: they were vs’d to bend
To ſend their ſmiles before them to Achilles:
To come as humbly as they vs’d to creepe to holy Altars.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What am I poore of late?
‘Tis certaine, greatneſſe once falne out with fortune,
Must fall out with men too: what the declin’d is,
He ſhall as ſoone reade in the eyes of others,
As feele in his owne fall: for men like butter-flies,
Shew not their mealie wings, but to the Summer:
And not a man for being ſimply man,
Hath any honour; but honour’d for those honours
That are without him; as place, riches, and fauour,
Prizes of accident, as oft as merit:
Which when they fall, as being ſlippery ſtanders;
The loue that leand on them as ſlippery too,
Doth one plucke downe another, and together
Dye in the fall. But ‘tis not ſo with me;
Fortune and I are friends, I doe enioy
At ample point, all that I did poſſeſſe,
Saue these mens lookes: who do me thinkes finde out
Something not worth in me ſuch rich beholding,
As they haue often giuen. Here is Vliſſes,
Ile interrupt his reading: how now Vliſſes?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Now great Thetis Sonne.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What are you reading?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: A ſtrange fellow here
Writes me, that man, how dearely euer parted,
How much in hauing, or without, or in,
Cannot make boast to haue that which he hath;
Nor feeles not what he owes, but by reflection:
As when his vertues ſhining vpon others,
Heate them, and they retort that heate againe
To the first giuer.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: This is not ſtrange Vliſſes:
The beautie that is borne here in the face,
The bearer knowes not, but commends it ſelfe,
Not going from it ſelfe: but eye to eye oppos’d,
Salutes each other with each others forme.
For ſpeculation turnes not to it ſelfe,
Till it hath trauail’d, and is married there
Where it may ſee it ſelfe: this is not ſtrange at all.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: I doe not ſtraine it at the position,
It is familiar; but at the Authors drift,
Who in his circumstance, expresly proues
That no man is the Lord of any thing,
(Though in and of him there is much consisting,)
Till he communicate his parts to others:
Nor doth he of himselfe know them for ought,
Till he behold them formed in th 'applause,
Where they are extended: who like an arch reuerb'rate
The voyce againe; or like a gate of ſteele,
Fronting the Sunne, receiues and renders backe
His figure, and his heate. I was much rapt in this,
And apprehended here immediately:
The vnknowne Aiax;
Heauens what a man is there? a very Horse,
That has he knowes not what. Nature, what things there are.
Mo’t abiect in regard, and deare in vse.
What things againe mo’t deere in the esteeme,
And poore in worth: now ſhall we ſee to morrow,
An act that very chance doth throw vpon him?
Aiax renown’d? O heauens, what ſome men doe,
While ſome men leaue to doe!
How ſome men creepe in ſkittish fortunes hall,
Whiles others play the Ideots in her eyes:
How one man eates into anothers pride,
While pride is feasting in his wantonneſſe
To ſee these Grecian Lords; why, euen already,
They clap the lubber Aiax on the ſhoulder,
As if his foote were on braue Hectors brest,
And great Troy ſhrinking.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: I doe beleeue it:
For they past by me, as mysers doe by beggars,
Neither gaue to me good word, nor looke:
What are my deedes forgot?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Time hath (my Lord) a wallet at his backe,
Wherein he puts almes for obliuion:
A great ſiz’d monster of ingratitudes:
Those ſcraps are good deedes past,
Which are deuour’d as fast as they are made,
Forgot as ſoone as done: perseuerance, deere my Lord,
Keepes honor bright, to haue done, is to hang
Quite out of fashion, like a rustie male,
In monumentall mockrie: take the instant way,
For honour trauels in a ſtraight ſo narrow,
Where one but goes a breast, keepe then the paths
For emulation hath a thousand Sonnes,
That one by one pursue; if you giue way,
Or hedge aside from the direct forth right;
Like to an entred Tyde, they all rush by,
And leaue you hindmost:
Or like gallant Horse falne in first ranke,
Lye there for pauement to the abiect, neere
Ore-run and trampled on: then what they doe in present,
Though leſſe then yours in past, must ore-top yours:
For time is like a fashionable Hoste,
That ſlightly ſhakes his parting Guest by th’ hand;
And with his armes out-stretcht, as he would flye,
Graspes in the commer: the welcome euer ſmiles,
And farewels goes out ſighing: O let not vertue ſeeke
Remuneration for the thing it was: for beautie, wit,
High birth, vigor of bone, desert in ſeruice,
Loue, friendship, charity, are ſubiects all
To enuious and calumniating time:
One touch of nature makes the whole world kin:
That all with one consent praise new borne gaudes,
Though they are made and moulded of things past,
And goe to dust, that is a little guilt,
More laud then guilt oredusted.
The present eye praises the present obiect:
Then maruell not thou great and compleat man,
That all the Greekes begin to worship Aiax;
Since things in motion begin to catch the eye,
Then what not ſtirs: the cry went out on thee,
And ſtill it might, and yet it may againe,
If thou would'st not entombe thy ſelfe aliue,
And case thy reputation in thy Tent;
Whose glorious deedes, but in these fields of late,
Made emulous miſſions 'mongst the gods themselues,
And draue great Mars to faction.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Of this my priuacie,
I haue ſtrong reasons.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: But 'gainst your priuacie
The reasons are more potent and heroycall:
‘Tis knowne Achilles, that you are in loue
With one of Priams daughters.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Ha? knowne?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Is that a wonder? The prouidence that’s in a watchfull State, Knowes almost euery graine of Plutœs gold; Findes bottome in th’ vncomprehensiue deepes; Keepes place with thought; and almost like the gods, Doe thoughts vnuaile in their dumbe cradles: There is a mysterie (with whom relation durst neuer meddle) in the ſoule of State; Which hath an operation more diuine, Then breath or pen can giue expreſſure to: All the commerse that you haue had with Troy, As perfectly is ours, as yours, my Lord. And better would it fit Achilles much, To throw downe Hector then Polixena. But it must grieue yong Pirhus now at home, When fame ſhall in her Iland ſound her trumpe; And all the Greekish Girles ſhall tripping ſing, Great Hectors ſister did Achilles winne; But our great Aiax brauely beate downe him. Farewell my Lord: I as your louer ſpeake; The foole ſlides ore the Ice that you ſhould breake.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: To this effect Achilles haue I mou’d you;
A woman impudent and mannish growne,
Is not more loth’d, then an effeminate man,
In time of action: I ſtand condemn’d for this;
They thinke my little ſtomacke to the warre,
And your great loue to me, restraines you thus:
Sweete, rouse your ſelfe; and the weake wanton Cupid
Shall from your necke vnloose his amorous fould,
And like a dew drop from the Lyons mane,
Be ſhooke to ayrie ayre.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Shall Aiax fight with Hector?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: I, and perhaps receiue much honor by him.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: I ſee my reputation is at ſtake,
My fame is ſhrowdly gored.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: O then beware:
Those wounds heale ill, that men doe giue themselues:
Omiſſion to doe what is neceſſary,
Seales a commiſſion to a blanke of danger,
And danger like an ague ſubtly taints
Euen then when we ſit idely in the ſunne.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Goe call Thersites hither ſweet Patroclus,
Ile ſend the foole to Aiax, and desire him
T' inuite the Troian Lords after the Combat
To ſee vs here vnarm’d: I haue a womans longing,
An appetite that I am ſicke withall,
To ſee great Hector in his weedes of peace;
To talke with him, and to behold his visage,
Euen to my full of view. A labour ſau’d.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: A wonder.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Aiax goes vp and downe the field, asking for himselfe.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: How ſo?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Hee must fight ſingly to morrow with Hector, and is ſo prophetically proud of an heroicall cudgelling, that he raues in ſaying nothing.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: How can that be?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Why he ſtalkes vp and downe like a Peacock, a ſtride and a ſtand: ruminates like an hosteſſe, that hath no Arithmatique but her braine to ſet downe her recko-ning: bites his lip with a politique regard, as who ſhould ſay, there were wit in his head and twoo’d out; and ſo there is: but it lyes as coldly in him, as fire in a flint, which will not ſhew without knocking. The mans vn-done for euer; for if Hector breake not his necke i'th’ com-bat, heele break't himselfe in vaine-glory. He knowes not mee: I ſaid, good morrow Aiax; And he replyes, thankes Agamemnon. What thinke you of this man, that takes me for the Generall? Hee's growne a very land-fish, languageleſſe, a monster: a plague of o-pinion, a man may weare it on both ſides like a leather Ierkin.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Thou must be my Ambaſſador to him Thersites.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Who, I: why, heele anſwer no body: he pro-feſſes not answering; ſpeaking is for beggers: he weares his tongue in's armes: I will put on his presence; let Pa-troclus make his demands to me, you ſhall ſee the Page-ant of Aiax.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: To him Patroclus; tell him, I humbly desire the valiant Aiax, to inuite the mo’t valorous Hector, to come vnarm’d to my Tent, and to procure ſafe conduct for his person, of the magnanimious and mo’t illustrious, ſixe or ſeauen times honour’d Captaine, Generall of the Grecian Armie Agamemnon, &c. doe this.

speech.speaker: Patro.
speech.line: Ioue bleſſe great Aiax.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Hum.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: I come from the worthy Achilles.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Ha?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Who mo’t humbly desires you to inuite Hector to his Tent.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Hum.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: And to procure ſafe conduct from Agamemnon.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Agamemnon?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: I my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Ha?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: What ſay you too't.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: God buy you with all my heart.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Your anſwer ſir.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: If to morrow be a faire day, by eleuen a clocke it will goe one way or other; howsœuer, he ſhall pay for me ere he has me.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Your anſwer ſir.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Fare you well with all my heart.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Why, but he is not in this tune, is he?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: No, but he's out a tune thus: what musicke will be in him when Hector has knockt out his braines, I know not: but I am ſure none, vnleſſe the Fidler Apollo get his ſinewes to make catlings on.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Come, thou ſhalt beare a Letter to him ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Let me carry another to his Horse; for that’s the more capable creature.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: My minde is troubled like a Fountaine ſtir’d,
And I my ſelfe ſee not the bottome of it.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Would the Fountaine of your minde were cleere againe, that I might water an Aſſe at it: I had rather be a Ticke in a Sheepe, then ſuch a valiant ignorance.

scene.stagedir: Enter at one doore Aeneas with a Torch, at another Paris, Diephœbus, Anthenor, Diomed the Grecian, with Torches

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: See hoa, who is that there?

speech.speaker: Dieph.
speech.line: It is the Lord Aeneas.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Is the Prince there in person?
Had I ſo good occasion to lye long
As you Prince Paris, nothing but heauenly busineſſe,
Should rob my bed-mate of my company.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: That's my minde too: good morrow Lord
Aeneas.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: A valiant Greeke Aeneas, take his hand,
Witneſſe the proceſſe of your ſpeech within;
You told how Diomed, in a whole weeke by dayes
Did haunt you in the Field.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Health to you valiant ſir,
During all question of the gentle truce:
But when I meete you arm’d, as blacke defiance,
As heart can thinke, or courage execute.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: The one and other Diomed embraces,
Our blouds are now in calme; and ſo long health:
But when contention, and occasion meetes,
By Ioue, Ile play the hunter for thy life,
With all my force, pursuite and pollicy.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: And thou ſhalt hunt a Lyon that will flye
With his face backward, in humaine gentleneſſe:
Welcome to Troy; now by Anchises life,
Welcome indeede: by Venus hand I ſweare,
No man aliue can loue in ſuch a ſort,
The thing he meanes to kill, more excellently.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: We ſimpathize. Ioue let Aeneas liue
(If to my ſword his fate be not the glory)
A thousand compleate courses of the Sunne,
But in mine emulous honor let him dye:
With euery ioynt a wound, and that to morrow.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: We know each other well.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: We doe, and long to know each other worse.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: This is the mo’t, despightful'st gentle greeting;
The noblest hatefull loue, that ere I heard of.
What busineſſe Lord ſo early?

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: I was ſent for to the King; but why, I know not.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: His purpose meets you; it was to bring this Greek
To Calcha's house; and there to render him,
For the enfreed Anthenor, the faire Creſſid:
Lets haue your company; or if you please,
Haste there before vs. I constantly doe thinke,
(Or rather call my thought a certaine knowledge)
My brother Troylus lodges there to night.
Rouse him, and giue him note of our approach,
With the whole quality whereof, I feare
We ſhall be much vnwelcome.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: That I aſſure you:
Troylus had rather Troy were borne to Greece,
Then Creſſid borne from Troy.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: There is no helpe:
The bitter disposition of the time will haue it ſo.
On Lord, weele follow you.

speech.speaker: Aene
speech.line: Good morrow all. Exit Aeneas

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: And tell me noble Diomed: faith tell me true,
Euen in the ſoule of ſound good fellowship,
Who in your thoughts merits faire Helen mo’t?
My ſelfe, or Menelaus?

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: Both alike.
He merits well to haue her, that doth ſeeke her,
Not making any ſcruple of her ſoylure,
With ſuch a hell of paine, and world of charge.
And you as well to keepe her, that defend her,
Not pallating the taste of her dishonour,
With ſuch a costly loſſe of wealth and friends:
He like a puling Cuckold, would drinke vp
The lees and dregs of a flat tamed peece:
You like a letcher, out of whorish loynes,
Are pleas’d to breede out your inheritors:
Both merits poyz’d, each weighs no leſſe nor more,
But he as he, which heauier for a whore.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: You are too bitter to your country-woman.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Shee's bitter to her countrey: heare me Paris,
For euery false drop in her baudy veines,
A Grecians life hath ſunke: for euery ſcruple
Of her contaminated carrion weight,
A Troian hath beene ſlaine. Since ſhe could ſpeake,
She hath not giuen ſo many good words breath,
As for her, Greekes and Troians ſuffred death.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Faire Diomed, you doe as chapmen doe,
Dispraise the thing that you desire to buy:
But we in ſilence hold this vertue well;
Weele not commend, what we intend to ſell.
Here lyes our way.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Deere trouble not your ſelfe: the morne is cold.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Then ſweet my Lord, Ile call mine Vnckle down;
He ſhall vnbolt the Gates.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Trouble him not:
To bed, to bed: ſleepe kill those pritty eyes,
And giue as ſoft attachment to thy ſences,
As Infants empty of all thought.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Good morrow then.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I prithee now to bed.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Are you a weary of me?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: O Creſſida! but that the busie day
Wak't by the Larke, hath rouz’d the ribauld Crowes,
And dreaming night will hide our eyes no longer:
I would not from thee.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Night hath beene too briefe.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Beshrew the witch! with venemous wights ſhe ſtayes,
As hidiously as hell; but flies the graspes of loue,
With wings more momentary, ſwift then thought:
You will catch cold, and curse me.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Prithee tarry, you men will neuer tarry;
O foolish Creſſid, I might haue ſtill held off,
And then you would haue tarried. Harke, ther's one vp?
Pand. within.
What's all the doores open here?

speech.speaker: Troy
speech.line: It is your Vnckle.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: A pestilence on him: now will he be mocking:
I ſhall haue ſuch a life.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: How now, how now? how goe maiden-heads?
Heare you Maide: wher's my cozin Creſſid?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Go hang your ſelf, you naughty mocking Vnckle:
You bring me to doo — and then you floute me too.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: To do what? to do what? let her ſay what:
What haue I brought you to doe?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Come, come, beshrew your heart: youle nere be good, nor ſuffer others.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Ha, ha: alas poore wretch: a poore Chipochia, hast not ſlept to night? would he not (a naughty man) let it ſleepe: a bug-beare take him.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Did not I tell you? would he were knockt ith' head. Who's that at doore? good Vnckle goe and ſee. My Lord, come you againe into my Chamber: You ſmile and mocke me, as if I meant naughtily.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Ha, ha.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Come you are deceiu’d, I thinke of no ſuch thing.
How earnestly they knocke: pray you come in.
I would not for halfe Troy haue you ſeene here.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Who's there? what’s the matter? will you beate downe the doore? How now, what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Good morrow Lord, good morrow.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Who's there my Lord Aeneas? by my troth I knew you not: what newes with you ſo early?

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Is not Prince Troylus here?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Here? what ſhould he doe here?

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Come he is here, my Lord, doe not deny him:
It doth import him much to ſpeake with me.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Is he here ſay you? ‘tis more then I know, Ile be ſworne: For my owne part I came in late: what ſhould he doe here?

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Who, nay then: Come, come, youle doe him wrong, ere y'are ware: youle be ſo true to him, to be false to him: Doe not you know of him, but yet goe fetch him hither, goe.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: How now, what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: My Lord, I ſcarce haue leisure to ſalute you,
My matter is ſo rash: there is at hand,
Paris your brother, and Deiphœbus,
The Grecian Diomed, and our Anthenor
Deliuer’d to vs, and for him forth-with,
Ere the first ſacrifice, within this houre,
We must giue vp to Diomeds hand
The Lady Creſſida.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Is it concluded ſo?

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: By Priam, and the generall ſtate of Troy,
They are at hand, and ready to effect it.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: How my atchieuements mocke me;
I will goe meete them: and my Lord Aeneas,
We met by chance; you did not finde me here.

speech.speaker: Aen.
speech.line: Good, good, my Lord, the ſecrets of nature
Haue not more gift in taciturnitie.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Is't poſſible? no ſooner got but lost: the diuell take Anthenor; the yong Prince will goe mad: a plague vpon Anthenor; I would they had brok's necke.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: How now? what’s the matter? who was here?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Ah, ha!

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Why ſigh you ſo profoundly? wher's my Lord? gone? tell me ſweet Vnckle, what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Would I were as deepe vnder the earth as I am aboue.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: O the gods! what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Prythee get thee in: would thou had'st nere been borne; I knew thou would'st be his death. O poore Gen-tleman: a plague vpon Anthenor.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Good Vnckle I beseech you, on my knees, I be-seech you what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Thou must be gone wench, thou must be gone; thou art chang’d for Anthenor: thou must to thy Father, and be gone from Troylus: 'twill be his death: 'twill be his baine, he cannot beare it.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: O you immortall gods! I will not goe.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Thou must.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: I will not Vnckle: I haue forgot my Father:
I know no touch of consanguinitie:
No kin, no loue, no bloud, no ſoule, ſo neere me,
As the ſweet Troylus: O you gods diuine!
Make Creſſids name the very crowne of falshood!
If euer ſhe leaue Troylus: time, force and death,
Do to this body what extremitie you can;
But the ſtrong base and building of my loue,
Is as the very Center of the earth,
Drawing all things to it. I will goe in and weepe.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Doe, doe.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Teare my bright heire, and ſcratch my praised cheekes, Cracke my cleere voyce with ſobs, and breake my heart With ſounding Troylus. I will not goe from Troy.

scene.stagedir: Enter Paris, Troylus, Aeneas, Deiphebus, An-thenor and Diomedes

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: It is great morning, and the houre prefixt
Of her deliuerie to this valiant Greeke
Comes fast vpon: good my brother Troylus,
Tell you the Lady what ſhe is to doe,
And hast her to the purpose.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Walke into her house.
Ile bring her to the Grecian presently;
And to his hand, when I deliuer her,
Thinke it an Altar, and thy brother Troylus
A Priest, there offring to it his heart.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: I know what ‘tis to loue,
And would, as I ſhall pittie, I could helpe.
Please you walke in, my Lords.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Be moderate, be moderate.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Why tell you me of moderation?
The griefe is fine, full perfect that I taste,
And no leſſe in a ſense as ſtrong
As that which causeth it. How can I moderate it?
If I could temporise with my affection,
Or brew it to a weake and colder pallat,
The like alaiment could I giue my griefe:
My loue admits no qualifying croſſe;
No more my griefe, in ſuch a precious loſſe.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Here, here, here, he comes, a ſweet ducke.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: O Troylus, Troylus!

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: What a paire of ſpectacles is here? let me em-brace too: oh hart, as the goodly ſaying is; O heart, hea-uie heart, why ſighest thou without breaking? where he answers againe; because thou canst not ease thy ſmart by friendship, not by ſpeaking: there was neuer a truer rime; let vs cast away nothing, for we may liue to haue neede of ſuch a Verse: we ſee it, we ſee it: how now Lambs?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Creſſid: I loue thee in ſo ſtrange a puritie;
That the blest gods, as angry with my fancie,
More bright in zeale, then the deuotion which
Cold lips blow to their Deities: take thee from me.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Haue the gods enuie?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I, I, I, I, ‘tis too plaine a case.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: And is it true, that I must goe from Troy?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: A hatefull truth.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: What, and from Troylus too?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: From Troy, and Troylus.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Ist poſſible?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: And ſodainely, where iniurie of chance
Puts backe leaue-taking, iustles roughly by
All time of pause; rudely beguiles our lips
Of all reioyndure: forcibly preuents
Our lockt embrasures; ſtrangles our deare vowes,
Euen in the birth of our owne laboring breath.
We two, that with ſo many thousand ſighes
Did buy each other, must poorely ſell our ſelues,
With the rude breuitie and discharge of our
Iniurious time; now with a robbers haste
Crams his rich theeuerie vp, he knowes not how.
As many farwels as be ſtars in heauen,
With distinct breath, and consign’d kiſſes to them,
He fumbles vp into a loose adiew;
And ſcants vs with a ſingle famisht kiſſe,
Distasting with the ſalt of broken teares.
Aeneas within.
My Lord, is the Lady ready?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Harke, you are call’d: ſome ſay the genius ſo
Cries, come to him that instantly must dye.
Bid them haue patience: ſhe ſhall come anon.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Where are my teares? raine, to lay this winde,
Or my heart will be blowne vp by the root.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: I must then to the Grecians?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: No remedy.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: A wofull Creſſid 'mong'st the merry Greekes.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: When ſhall we ſee againe?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Here me my loue: be thou but true of heart.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: I true? how now? what wicked deeme is this?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Nay, we must vse expostulation kindely,
For it is parting from vs:
I ſpeake not, be thou true, as fearing thee:
For I will throw my Gloue to death himselfe,
That there's no maculation in thy heart:
But be thou true, ſay I, to fashion in
My ſequent protestation: be thou true,
And I will ſee thee.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: O you ſhall be expos’d, my Lord to dangers
As infinite, as imminent: but Ile be true.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: And Ile grow friend with danger;
Weare this Sleeue.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: And you this Gloue.
When ſhall I ſee you?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I will corrupt the Grecian Centinels,
To giue thee nightly visitation.
But yet be true.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: O heauens: be true againe?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Heare why I ſpeake it; Loue:
The Grecian youths are full of qualitie,
Their louing well compos’d, with guift of nature,
Flawing and ſwelling ore with Arts and exercise:
How nouelties may moue, and parts with person.
Alas, a kinde of godly iealousie;
Which I beseech you call a vertuous ſinne:
Makes me affraid.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: O heauens, you loue me not!

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Dye I a villaine then:
In this I doe not call your faith in question
So mainely as my merit: I cannot ſing,
Nor heele the high Lauolt; nor ſweeten talke;
Nor play at ſubtill games; faire vertues all;
To which the Grecians are mo’t prompt and pregnant:
But I can tell that in each grace of these,
There lurkes a ſtill and dumb-discoursiue diuell,
That tempts mo’t cunningly: but be not tempted.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Doe you thinke I will:

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: No, but ſomething may be done that we wil not:
And ſometimes we are diuels to our ſelues,
When we will tempt the frailtie of our powers,
Presuming on their changefull potencie.
Aeneas within.
Nay, good my Lord?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Come kiſſe, and let vs part.
Paris within.
Brother Troylus?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Good brother come you hither,
And bring Aeneas and the Grecian with you.

speech.speaker: Cres
speech.line: My Lord, will you be true?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Who I? alas it is my vice, my fault:
Whiles others fish with craft for great opinion,
I, with great truth, catch meere ſimplicitie;
Whil'st ſome with cunning guild their copper crownes,
With truth and plainneſſe I doe weare mine bare:
Feare not my truth; the morrall of my wit
Is plaine and true, ther's all the reach of it.
Welcome ſir Diomed, here is the Lady
Which for Antenor, we deliuer you.
At the port (Lord) Ile giue her to thy hand,
And by the way poſſeſſe thee what ſhe is.
Entreate her faire; and by my ſoule, faire Greeke,
If ere thou ſtand at mercy of my Sword,
Name Creſſid, and thy life ſhall be as ſafe
As Priam is in Illion?

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: Faire Lady Creſſid,
So please you ſaue the thankes this Prince expects:
The lustre in your eye, heauen in your cheeke,
Pleades your faire visage, and to Diomed
You ſhall be mistreſſe, and command him wholly.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Grecian, thou do'st not vse me curteously,
To ſhame the ſeale of my petition towards,
I praising her. I tell thee Lord of Greece:
Shee is as farre high ſoaring o’re thy praises,
As thou vnworthy to be cal’d her ſeruant:
I charge thee vse her well, euen for my charge:
For by the dreadfull Pluto, if thou do'st not,
(Though the great bulke Achilles be thy guard)
Ile cut thy throate.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: Oh be not mou’d Prince Troylus;
Let me be priuiledg’d by my place and meſſage,
To be a ſpeaker free? when I am hence,
Ile anſwer to my lust: and know my Lord;
Ile nothing doe on charge: to her owne worth
She ſhall be priz’d: but that you ſay, be't ſo;
Ile ſpeake it in my ſpirit and honor, no.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Come to the Port. Ile tell thee Diomed,
This braue, ſhall oft make thee to hide thy head:
Lady, giue me your hand, and as we walke,
To our owne ſelues bend we our needefull talke.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Harke, Hectors Trumpet.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: How haue we ſpent this morning
The Prince must thinke me tardy and remiſſe,
That ſwore to ride before him in the field.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: ‘Tis Troylus fault: come, come, to field with him.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Let vs make ready ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Yea, with a Bridegroomes fresh alacritie
Let vs addreſſe to tend on Hectors heeles:
The glory of our Troy doth this day lye
On his faire worth, and ſingle Chiualrie.

scene.stagedir: Enter Aiax armed, Achilles, Patroclus, Agamemnon, Menelaus, Vliſſes, Nester, Calcas, &c

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Here art thou in appointment fresh and faire,
Anticipating time. With ſtarring courage,
Giue with thy Trumpet a loud note to Troy
Thou dreadfull Aiax, that the appauled aire
May pierce the head of the great Combatant,
And hale him hither.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Thou, Trumpet, ther's my purse;
Now cracke thy lungs, and ſplit thy brasen pipe:
Blow villaine, till thy ſphered Bias cheeke
Out-swell the collicke of puft Aquilon:
Come, ſtretch thy chest, and let thy eyes ſpout bloud:
Thou blowest for Hector.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: No Trumpet answers.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: ‘Tis but early dayes.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Is not yong Diomed with Calcas daughter?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: ‘Tis he, I ken the manner of his gate,
He rises on the tœ: that ſpirit of his
In aspiration lifts him from the earth.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Is this the Lady Creſſid?

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Euen ſhe.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Mo’t deerely welcome to the Greekes, ſweete
Lady.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: Our Generall doth ſalute you with a kiſſe.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Yet is the kindeneſſe but particular; 'twere bet-ter ſhe were kist in generall.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: And very courtly counsell: Ile begin. So much for Nestor.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Ile take that winter from your lips faire Lady
Achilles bids you welcome.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: I had good argument for kiſſing once.

speech.speaker: Patro.
speech.line: But that’s no argument for kiſſing now;
For thus pop't Paris in his hardiment.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Oh deadly gall, and theame of all our ſcornes,
For which we loose our heads, to gild his hornes.

speech.speaker: Patro.
speech.line: The first was Menelaus kiſſe, this mine:
Patroclus kiſſes you.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Oh this is trim.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Paris and I kiſſe euermore for him.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Ile haue my kiſſe ſir: Lady by your leaue.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: In kiſſing doe you render, or receiue.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Both take and giue.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Ile make my match to liue, The kiſſe you take is better then you giue: therefore no kiſſe.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Ile giue you boote, Ile giue you three for one.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: You are an odde man, giue euen, or giue none.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: An odde man Lady, euery man is odde.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: No, Paris is not; for you know ‘tis true,
That you are odde, and he is euen with you.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: You fillip me a'th’ head.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: No, Ile be ſworne.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: It were no match, your naile against his horne:
May I ſweete Lady beg a kiſſe of you?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: You may.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: I doe desire it.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Why begge then?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Why then for Venus ſake, giue me a kiſſe:
When Hellen is a maide againe, and his—

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: I am your debtor, claime it when ‘tis due.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Neuer's my day, and then a kiſſe of you.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: Lady a word, Ile bring you to your Father.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: A woman of quicke ſence.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Fie, fie, vpon her: Ther's a language in her eye, her cheeke, her lip; Nay, her foote ſpeakes, her wanton ſpirites looke out At euery ioynt, and motiue of her body: Oh these encounterers ſo glib of tongue, That giue a coasting welcome ere it comes; And wide vnclaspe the tables of their thoughts, To euery tickling reader: ſet them downe, For ſluttish ſpoyles of opportunitie: And daughters of the game. Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Enter all of Troy, Hector, Paris, Aeneas, Helenus and Attendants. Florish

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: The Troians Trumpet.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Yonder comes the troope.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Haile all you ſtate of Greece: what ſhalbe done
To him that victory commands? or doe you purpose,
A victor ſhall be knowne: will you the Knights
Shall to the edge of all extremitie
Pursue each other; or ſhall be diuided
By any voyce, or order of the field: Hector bad aske?

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Which way would Hector haue it?

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: He cares not, heele obey conditions.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: ‘Tis done like Hector, but ſecurely done,
A little proudly, and great deale disprising
The Knight oppos’d.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: If not Achilles ſir, what is your name?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: If not Achilles, nothing.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Therefore Achilles: but what ere, know this,
In the extremity of great and little:
Valour and pride excell themselues in Hector;
The one almost as infinite as all;
The other blanke as nothing: weigh him well:
And that which lookes like pride, is curtesie:
This Aiax is halfe made of Hectors bloud;
In loue wherof, halfe Hector ſtaies at home:
Halfe heart, halfe hand, halfe Hector, comes to ſeeke
This blended Knight, halfe Troian, and halfe Greeke.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: A maiden battaile then? O I perceiue you.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Here is ſir, Diomed: goe gentle Knight,
Stand by our Aiax: as you and Lord Aeneas
Consent vpon the order of their fight,
So be it: either to the vttermost,
Or else a breach: the Combatants being kin,
Halfe ſtints their ſtrife, before their ſtrokes begin.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: They are oppos’d already.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: What Troian is that ſame that lookes ſo heauy?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: The yongest Sonne of Priam;
A true Knight; they call him Troylus;
Not yet mature, yet matchleſſe, firme of word,
Speaking in deedes, and deedeleſſe in his tongue;
Not ſoone prouok't, nor being prouok't, ſoone calm’d;
His heart and hand both open, and both free:
For what he has, he giues; what thinkes, he ſhewes;
Yet giues he not till iudgement guide his bounty,
Nor dignifies an impaire thought with breath:
Manly as Hector, but more dangerous;
For Hector in his blaze of wrath ſubscribes
To tender obiects; but he, in heate of action,
Is more vindecatiue then iealous loue.
They call him Troylus; and on him erect,
A ſecond hope, as fairely built as Hector.
Thus ſaies Aeneas, one that knowes the youth,
Euen to his inches: and with priuate ſoule,
Did in great Illion thus translate him to me.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: They are in action.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: Now Aiax hold thine owne.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Hector, thou ſleep'st, awake thee.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: His blowes are wel dispos’d there Aiax.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: You must no more.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: Princes enough, ſo please you.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: I am not warme yet, let vs fight againe.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: As Hector pleases.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Why then will I no more:
Thou art great Lord, my Fathers ſisters Sonne;
A cousen german to great Priams ſeede:
The obligation of our bloud forbids
A gorie emulation 'twixt vs twaine:
Were thy commixion, Greeke and Troian ſo,
That thou could'st ſay, this hand is Grecian all,
And this is Troian: the ſinewes of this Legge,
All Greeke, and this all Troy: my Mothers bloud
Runs on the dexter cheeke, and this ſinister
Bounds in my fathers: by Ioue multipotent,
Thou ſhould'st not beare from me a Greekish member
Wherein my ſword had not impreſſure made
Of our ranke feud: but the iust gods gainsay,
That any drop thou borrowd'st from thy mother,
My ſacred Aunt, ſhould by my mortall Sword
Be drained. Let me embrace thee Aiax:
By him that thunders, thou hast lustie Armes;
Hector would haue them fall vpon him thus.
Cozen, all honor to thee.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: I thanke thee Hector:
Thou art too gentle, and too free a man:
I came to kill thee Cozen, and beare hence
A great addition, earned in thy death.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Not Neoptolymus ſo mirable,
On whose bright crest, fame with her lowd'st (Oyes)
Cries, This is he; could'st promise to himselfe,
A thought of added honor, torne from Hector.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: There is expectance here from both the ſides,
What further you will doe?

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Weele answere it:
The iſſue is embracement: Aiax, farewell.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: If I might in entreaties finde ſucceſſe,
As ſeld I haue the chance; I would desire
My famous Cousin to our Grecian Tents.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: ‘Tis Agamemnons wish, and great Achilles
Doth long to ſee vnarm’d the valiant Hector.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Aeneas, call my brother Troylus to me:
And ſignifie this louing enterview
To the expecters of our Troian part:
Desire them home. Giue me thy hand, my Cousin:
I will goe eate with thee, and ſee your Knights.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Great Agamemnon comes to meete vs here.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: The worthiest of them, tell me name by name:
But for Achilles, mine owne ſerching eyes
Shall finde him by his large and portly ſize.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Worthy of Armes: as welcome as to one
That would be rid of ſuch an enemie.
But that’s no welcome: vnderstand more cleere
What's past, and what’s to come, is ſtrew’d with huskes
And formeleſſe ruine of obliuion:
But in this extant moment, faith and troth,
Strain’d purely from all hollow bias drawing:
Bids thee with mo’t diuine integritie,
From heart of very heart, great Hector welcome.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: I thanke thee mo’t imperious Agamemnon.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: My well-fam’d Lord of Troy, no leſſe to you.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Let me confirme my Princely brothers greeting,
You brace of warlike Brothers, welcome hither.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Who must we anſwer?

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: The Noble Menelaus.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: O, you my Lord, by Mars his gauntlet thanks,
Mocke not, that I affect th’ vntraded Oath,
Your quondam wife ſweares ſtill by Venus Gloue
Shee's well, but bad me not commend her to you.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Name her not now ſir, ſhe's a deadly Theame.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: O pardon, I offend.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: I haue (thou gallant Troyan) ſeene thee oft
Labouring for destiny, make cruell way
Through rankes of Greekish youth: and I haue ſeen thee
As hot as Perseus, ſpurre thy Phrygian Steed,
And ſeene thee ſcorning forfeits and ſubduments,
When thou hast hung thy aduanced ſword i'th’ ayre,
Not letting it decline, on the declined:
That I haue ſaid vnto my ſtanders by,
Lœ Iupiter is yonder, dealing life.
And I haue ſeene thee pause, and take thy breath,
When that a ring of Greekes haue hem’d thee in,
Like an Olympian wrestling. This haue I ſeene,
But this thy countenance (still lockt in ſteele)
I neuer ſaw till now. I knew thy Grandsire,
And once fought with him; he was a Souldier good,
But by great Mars, the Captaine of vs all,
Neuer like thee. Let an oldman embrace thee,
And (worthy Warriour) welcome to our Tents.

speech.speaker: Aene.
speech.line: ‘Tis the old Nestor.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Let me embrace thee good old Chronicle,
That hast ſo long walk’d hand in hand with time:
Mo’t reuerend Nestor, I am glad to claspe thee.

speech.speaker: Ne.
speech.line: I would my armes could match thee in contention
As they contend with thee in courtesie.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: I would they could.

speech.speaker: Nest.
speech.line: Ha? by this white beard I'ld fight with thee to morrow. Well, welcom, welcome: I haue ſeen the time.

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: I wonder now, how yonder City ſtands,
When we haue heere her Base and pillar by vs.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: I know your fauour Lord Vlyſſes well.
Ah ſir, there's many a Greeke and Troyan dead,
Since first I ſaw your ſelfe, and Diomed
In Illion, on your Greekish Embaſſie.

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: Sir, I foretold you then what would ensue.
My prophesie is but halfe his iourney yet;
For yonder wals that pertly front your Towne,
Yond Towers, whose wanton tops do buſſe the clouds,
Must kiſſe their owne feet.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: I must not beleeue you:
There they ſtand yet: and modestly I thinke,
The fall of euery Phrygian ſtone will cost
A drop of Grecian blood: the end crownes all,
And that old common Arbitrator, Time,
Will one day end it.

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: So to him we leaue it.
Mo’t gentle, and mo’t valiant Hector, welcome;
After the Generall, I beseech you next
To Feast with me, and ſee me at my Tent.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: I ſhall forestall thee Lord Vlyſſes, thou:
Now Hector I haue fed mine eyes on thee,
I haue with exact view perus’d thee Hector,
And quoted ioynt by ioynt.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Is this Achilles?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: I am Achilles.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Stand faire I prythee, let me looke on thee.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Behold thy fill.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Nay, I haue done already.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Thou art to breefe, I will the ſecond time,
As I would buy thee, view thee, limbe by limbe.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: O like a Booke of ſport thou'lt reade me ore:
But there's more in me then thou vnderstand'st.
Why doest thou ſo oppreſſe me with thine eye?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Tell me you Heauens, in which part of his body
Shall I destroy him? Whether three, or there, or there,
That I may giue the locall wound a name,
And make distinct the very breach, where-out
Hectors great ſpirit flew. Answer me heauens.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: It would discredit the blest Gods, proud man,
To anſwer ſuch a question: Stand againe;
Think'st thou to catch my life ſo pleasantly,
As to prenominate in nice coniecture
Where thou wilt hit me dead?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: I tell thee yea.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Wert thou the Oracle to tell me ſo,
I'ld not beleeue thee: henceforth guard thee well,
For Ile not kill thee there, not there, nor there,
But by the forge that ſtythied Mars his helme,
Ile kill thee euery where, yea, ore and ore.
You wisest Grecians, pardon me this bragge,
His insolence drawes folly from my lips,
But Ile endeuour deeds to match these words,
Or may I neuer—

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: Do not chafe thee Cosin:
And you Achilles, let these threats alone
Till accident, or purpose bring you too't.
You may euery day enough of Hector
If you haue ſtomacke. The generall ſtate I feare,
Can ſcarse intreat you to be odde with him.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: I pray you let vs ſee you in the field,
We haue had pelting Warres ſince you refus’d
The Grecians cause.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Dost thou intreat me Hector?
To morrow do I meete thee fell as death,
To night, all Friends.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Thy hand vpon that match.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: First, all you Peeres of Greece go to my Tent,
There in the full conuiue you: Afterwards,
As Hectors leysure, and your bounties ſhall
Concurre together, ſeuerally intreat him.
Beate lowd the Taborins, let the Trumpets blow,
That this great Souldier may his welcome know.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: My Lord Vlyſſes, tell me I beseech you,
In what place of the Field doth Calchas keepe?

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: At Menelaus Tent, mo’t Princely Troylus,
There Diomed doth feast with him to night,
Who neither lookes on heauen, nor on earth,
But giues all gaze and bent of amorous view
On the faire Creſſid.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Shall I (sweet Lord) be bound to thee ſo much,
After we part from Agamemnons Tent,
To bring me thither?

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: You ſhall command me ſir:
As gentle tell me, of what Honour was
This Creſſida in Troy, had ſhe no Louer there
That wailes her absence?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: O ſir, to ſuch as boasting ſhew their ſcarres,
A mocke is due: will you walke on my Lord?
She was belou’d, ſhe lou’d; ſhe is, and dooth;
But ſtill ſweet Loue is food for Fortunes tooth.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Ile heat his blood with Greekish wine to night,
Which with my Cemitar Ile coole to morrow:
Patroclus, let vs Feast him to the hight.

speech.speaker: Pat
speech.line: Heere comes Thersites.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: How now, thou core of Enuy?
Thou crusty batch of Nature, what’s the newes?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Why thou picture of what thou ſeem'st, & Idoll of Ideot-worshippers, here's a Letter for thee.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: From whence, Fragment?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Why thou full dish of Foole, from Troy.

speech.speaker: Pat.
speech.line: Who keepes the Tent now?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: The Surgeons box, or the Patients wound.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Well ſaid aduersity, and what need these tricks?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Prythee be ſilent boy, I profit not by thy talke, thou art thought to be Achilles male Varlot.

speech.speaker: Patro.
speech.line: Male Varlot you Rogue? What's that?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Why his masculine Whore. Now the rotten diseases of the South, guts-griping Ruptures, Catarres, Loades a grauell i'th’ backe, Lethargies, cold Palsies, and the like, take and take againe, ſuch prepostrous discoue-ries. _

speech.speaker: Pat.
speech.line: Why thou damnable box of enuy thou, what mean'st thou to curse thus?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Do I curse thee?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Why no, you ruinous But, you whorson indi-stinguishable
Curre.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: No? why art thou then exasperate, thou idle, immateriall ſkiene of Sleyd ſilke; thou greene Sarcenet flap for a ſore eye, thou taſſell of a Prodigals purse thou: Ah how the poore world is pestred with ſuch water-flies, diminutiues of Nature.

speech.speaker: Pat.
speech.line: Out gall.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Finch Egge.

speech.speaker: Ach.
speech.line: My ſweet Patroclus, I am thwarted quite
From my great purpose in to morrowes battell:
Heere is a Letter from Queene Hecuba,
A token from her daughter, my faire Loue,
Both taxing me, and gaging me to keepe
An Oath that I haue ſworne. I will not breake it,
Fall Greekes, faile Fame, Honor or go, or ſtay,
My maior vow lyes heere; this Ile obay:
Come, come Thersites, helpe to trim my Tent,
This night in banquetting must all be ſpent.
Away Patroclus.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: With too much bloud, and too little Brain, these two may run mad: but if with too much braine, and too little blood, they do, Ile be a curer of madmen. Heere's Agamemnon, an honeſt fellow enough, and one that loues Quailes, but he has not ſo much Braine as eare-wax; and the goodly transformation of Iupiter there his Brother, the Bull, the primatiue Statue, and oblique memoriall of Cuckolds, a thrifty ſhooing-horne in a chaine, hanging at his Brothers legge, to what forme but that he is, ſhold wit larded with malice, and malice forced with wit, turne him too: to an Aſſe were nothing; hee is both Aſſe and Oxe; to an Oxe were nothing, hee is both Oxe and Aſſe: to be a Dogge, a Mule, a Cat, a Fitchew, a Toade, a Li-zard, an Owle, a Puttocke, or a Herring without a Rœ, I would not care: but to be Menelaus, I would conspire against Destiny. Aske me not what I would be, if I were not Thersites: for I care not to bee the lowse of a Lazar, ſo I were not Menelaus. Hoy-day, ſpirits and fires.

scene.stagedir: Enter Hector, Aiax, Agamemnon, Vlyſſes, Ne-stor, Diomed, with Lights

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: We go wrong, we go wrong.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: No yonder ‘tis, there where we ſee the light.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: I trouble you.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: No, not a whit.

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: Heere comes himselfe to guide you?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Welcome braue Hector, welcome Princes all.

speech.speaker: Agam.
speech.line: So now faire Prince of Troy, I bid goodnight,
Aiax commands the guard to tend on you.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Thanks, and goodnight to the Greeks general.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Goodnight my Lord.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Goodnight ſweet Lord Menelaus.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Sweet draught: ſweet quoth-a? ſweet ſinke, ſweet ſure.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Goodnight and welcom, both at once, to those that go, or tarry.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Goodnight.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Old Nestor tarries, and you too Diomed,
Keepe Hector company an houre, or two.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: I cannot Lord, I haue important busineſſe,
The tide whereof is now, goodnight great Hector.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: Giue me your hand.

speech.speaker: Vlys.
speech.line: Follow his Torch, he goes to Chalcas Tent,
Ile keepe you company.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Sweet ſir, you honour me.

speech.speaker: Hect.
speech.line: And ſo good night.

speech.speaker: Achil
speech.line: Come, come, enter my Tent.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: That ſame Diomed's a false-hearted Rogue, a mo’t vniust Knaue; I will no more trust him when hee leeres, then I will a Serpent when he hiſſes: he will ſpend his mouth & promise, like Brabler the Hound; but when he performes, Astronomers foretell it, that it is prodigi-ous, there will come ſome change: the Sunne borrowes of the Moone when Diomed keepes his word. I will ra-ther leaue to ſee Hector, then not to dogge him: they ſay, he keepes a Troyan Drab, and vses the Traitour Chalcas his Tent. Ile after — Nothing but Letcherie? All incontinent Varlets. Exeunt

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: What are you vp here ho? ſpeake?

speech.speaker: Chal.
speech.line: Who cals?

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Diomed, Chalcas (I thinke) wher's your Daughter?

speech.speaker: Chal.
speech.line: She comes to you.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Stand where the Torch may not discouer vs.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Creſſid comes forth to him.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: How now my charge?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Now my ſweet gardian: harke a word with you.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Yea, ſo familiar?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: She will ſing any man at first ſight.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: And any man may finde her, if he can take her life: ſhe's noted.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Will you remember?

speech.speaker: Cal.
speech.line: Remember? yes.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Nay, but doe then; and let your minde be cou-pled with your words.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: What ſhould ſhe remember?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: List?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Sweete hony Greek, tempt me no more to folly.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Roguery.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Nay then.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Ile tell you what.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Fo, fo, come tell a pin, you are a forsworne.—

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: In faith I cannot: what would you haue me do?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: A iugling tricke, to be ſecretly open.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: What did you ſweare you would bestow on me?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: I prethee do not hold me to mine oath,
Bid me doe not any thing but that ſweete Greeke.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Good night.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Hold, patience.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: How now Troian?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Diomed.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: No, no, good night: Ile be your foole no more.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Thy better must.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Harke one word in your eare.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: O plague and madneſſe!

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: You are moued Prince, let vs depart I pray you,
Lest your displeasure ſhould enlarge it ſelfe
To wrathfull tearmes: this place is dangerous;
The time right deadly: I beseech you goe.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Behold, I pray you.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Nay, good my Lord goe off:
You flow to great distraction: come my Lord?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I pray thee ſtay?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: You haue not patience, come.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I pray you ſtay? by hell and hell torments,
I will not ſpeake a word.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: And ſo good night.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Nay, but you part in anger.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Doth that grieue thee? O withered truth!

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Why, how now Lord?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: By Ioue I will be patient.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Gardian? why Greeke?

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Fo, fo, adew, you palter.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: In faith I doe not: come hither once againe.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: You ſhake my Lord at ſomething; will you goe? you will breake out.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: She ſtroakes his cheeke.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Come, come.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Nay ſtay, by Ioue I will not ſpeake a word.
There is betweene my will, and all offences,
A guard of patience; ſtay a little while.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: How the diuell Luxury with his fat rumpe and potato finger, tickles these together: frye lechery, frye.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: But will you then?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: In faith I will lo; neuer trust me else.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Giue me ſome token for the ſurety of it.

speech.speaker: Cres
speech.line: Ile fetch you one.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: You haue ſworne patience.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Feare me not ſweete Lord.
I will not be my ſelfe, nor haue cognition
Of what I feele: I am all patience.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Now the pledge, now, now, now.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Here Diomed, keepe this Sleeue.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: O beautie! where is thy Faith?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I will be patient, outwardly I will.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: You looke vpon that Sleeue? behold it well:
He lou’d me: O false wench: giue't me againe.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Whose was't?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: It is no matter now I haue't againe.
I will not meete with you to morrow night:
I prythee Diomed visite me no more.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Now ſhe ſharpens: well ſaid Whetstone.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: I ſhall haue it.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: What, this?

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: I that.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: O all you gods! O prettie, prettie pledge;
Thy Maister now lies thinking in his bed
Of thee and me, and ſighes, and takes my Gloue,
And giues memoriall daintie kiſſes to it;
As I kiſſe thee.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Nay, doe not ſnatch it from me.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: He that takes that, takes my heart withall.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: I had your heart before, this followes it.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I did ſweare patience.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: You ſhall not haue it Diomed; faith you ſhall not:
Ile giue you ſomething else.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: I will haue this: whose was it?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: It is no matter.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Come tell me whose it was?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: 'Twas one that lou’d me better then you will.
But now you haue it, take it.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Whose was it?

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: By all Dianas waiting women yond:
And by her ſelfe, I will not tell you whose.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: To morrow will I weare it on my Helme,
And grieue his ſpirit that dares not challenge it.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Wert thou the diuell, and wor'st it on thy horne,
It ſhould be challeng’d.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Well, well, ‘tis done, ‘tis past; and yet it is not:
I will not keepe my word.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Why then farewell,
Thou neuer ſhalt mocke Diomed againe.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: You ſhall not goe: one cannot ſpeake a word,
But it ſtrait ſtarts you.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: I doe not like this fooling.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Nor I by Pluto: but that that likes not me, plea-ses me best.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: What ſhall I come? the houre.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: I, come: O Ioue! doe, come: I ſhall be plagu’d.

speech.speaker: Dio
speech.line: Farewell till then.

speech.speaker: Cres.
speech.line: Good night: I prythee come:
Troylus farewell; one eye yet lookes on thee;
But with my heart, the other eye, doth ſee.
Ah poore our ſexe; this fault in vs I finde:
The errour of our eye, directs our minde.
What errour leads, must erre: O then conclude,
Mindes ſwai’d by eyes, are full of turpitude.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: A proofe of ſtrength ſhe could not publish more;
Vnleſſe ſhe ſay, my minde is now turn’d whore.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Al's done my Lord.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: It is.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Why ſtay we then?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: To make a recordation to my ſoule
Of euery ſyllable that here was ſpoke:
But if I tell how these two did coact;
Shall I not lye, in publishing a truth?
Sith yet there is a credence in my heart:
An esperance ſo obstinately ſtrong,
That doth inuert that test of eyes and eares;
As if those organs had deceptious functions,
Created onely to calumniate.
Was Creſſed here?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: I cannot coniure Troian.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: She was not ſure.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Mo’t ſure ſhe was.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Why my negation hath no taste of madneſſe?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Nor mine my Lord: Creſſid was here but now.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Let it not be beleeu’d for womanhood:
Thinke we had mothers; doe not giue aduantage
To ſtubborne Criticks, apt without a theame
For deprauation, to ſquare the generall ſex
By Creſſids rule. Rather thinke this not Creſſid.

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: What hath ſhe done Prince, that can ſoyle our mothers?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Nothing at all, vnleſſe that this were ſhe.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Will he ſwagger himselfe out on's owne eyes?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: This ſhe? no, this is Diomeds Creſſida:
If beautie haue a ſoule, this is not ſhe:
If ſoules guide vowes; if vowes are ſanctimonie;
If ſanctimonie be the gods delight:
If there be rule in vnitie it ſelfe,
This is not ſhe: O madneſſe of discourse!
That cause ſets vp, with, and against thy ſelfe
By foule authoritie: where reason can reuolt
Without perdition, and loſſe aſſume all reason,
Without reuolt. This is, and is not Creſſid:
Within my ſoule, there doth conduce a ſight
Of this ſtrange nature, that a thing inseperate,
Diuides more wider then the ſkie and earth:
And yet the ſpacious bredth of this diuision,
Admits no Orifex for a point as ſubtle,
As Ariachnes broken woofe to enter:
